author: Louie Bacaj
first_line: Software engineering is probably 80% writing.
hook_150:
Software engineering is probably 80% writing. 

And I'm not talking about code:
- Jira Tickets
- Designs docs
- Presentations
- Emails & slack
- Docum
full_text:
Software engineering is probably 80% writing. 

And I'm not talking about code:
- Jira Tickets
- Designs docs
- Presentations
- Emails & slack
- Documentation
- Internal and external blog posts, etc.

You may not realize it, but you try to program humans more than machines.

author: Gregor Ojstersek
first_line: Tech Lead is one of the most desirable roles in tech.
hook_150:
Tech Lead is one of the most desirable roles in tech.

The reason?

A good mix of technical and people-related skills, which includes:
- common sense
full_text:
Tech Lead is one of the most desirable roles in tech.

The reason?

A good mix of technical and people-related skills, which includes:
- common sense and pragmatism,
- good communication and leadership,
- being a multiplier for others and making everyone around them better.

These skills do well in the AI era and are just going to be more and more important.

To learn how to become a Tech Lead -> join engineers and leads from Meta, Google, IBM, Revolut in my cohort-based course here: https://lnkd.in/exsYfM54 (we start on January 20).

author: Nicola Ballotta
first_line: Many Engineering Managers often believe that quickly expanding their teams will lead to getting more
hook_150:
Many Engineering Managers often believe that quickly expanding their teams will lead to getting more things done.


âŒ Wrong assumption.

In reality, s
full_text:
Many Engineering Managers often believe that quickly expanding their teams will lead to getting more things done.


âŒ Wrong assumption.

In reality, scaling a team quickly often leads to more issues.

Before scaling your team, it's crucial to:

ğŸ“‹ Establish effective processes and document them: this will ensure smoother onboarding and alignment with the existing team dynamics.

ğŸŒŸ Understand the Current Team's Capabilities: it's important to know what skills and strengths your current team has. This helps in understanding what new skills are needed in the team.

ğŸ¤ Ensure that the team is happy: hiring more people when there are team issues will increase friction.

ğŸš€ Implement a well-structured onboarding process: when you hire new people, it's important to have a streamlined onboarding approach, or there will be a high risk of losing them immediately.

ğŸ’¼ Define Clear Roles and Responsibilities: before hiring, be clear about the roles and responsibilities the new team members will have. This helps avoid overlap and confusion.

â“ Verify the genuine need for additional team members: don't hire just to follow a hiring roadmap you defined at the beginning of the year.

Have I missed anything?

â™»ï¸ PLEASE REPOST IF YOU FOUND IT USEFUL, IT MEANS A LOT TO ME.

author: Jordan Cutler
first_line: I'm thrilled to share that I've been promoted to Staff Software Engineer at Pinterest!
hook_150:
I'm thrilled to share that I've been promoted to Staff Software Engineer at Pinterest!

Working at Pinterest has been such a rewarding experience. I'v
full_text:
I'm thrilled to share that I've been promoted to Staff Software Engineer at Pinterest!

Working at Pinterest has been such a rewarding experience. I've grown so much since joining, and I'm grateful for my team (Web Platform) and org (Client Foundations) for creating an environment that makes it easy for that to happen.

I've had the chance to lead initiatives like optimizing how fast pins load, revamping navigation, and now driving developer experience across 8 teams. Throughout all of this, my team has been an amazing support system, with incredibly talented people to learn from. 

I also want to give a special shout-out to my manager Vasanth Krishnamoorthy, tech lead and mentor Yen-Wei L. , and Director Mark Cerqueira. You've made this year really special and I appreciate you ğŸ™

I'm looking forward to taking on even bigger challenges and starting yet another growth journey (it never stops ğŸš€).

author: Louie Bacaj
first_line: When Software Engineers from your teams leave and join companies like Google, FB, Apple, or a fast-g
hook_150: When Software Engineers from your teams leave and join companies like Google, FB, Apple, or a fast-growing Startup, or even start their own thing, you
full_text:
When Software Engineers from your teams leave and join companies like Google, FB, Apple, or a fast-growing Startup, or even start their own thing, you should be proud of that.

Of course, it sucks to lose someone good, but people will move around anyway. At least that means you did many things right. 

It means you hired right and the amount of growth people got after they joined you was high.

Who wouldn't be proud of that?

That's a badge of honor you can carry: 
"Our alumni go to great places"

It beats: 
"Our alumni end up in much crappier places than us"

author: Gergely Orosz
first_line: Talked with the Claude Code team on how they build Claude Code. It feels I get a peek into the futur
hook_150: Talked with the Claude Code team on how they build Claude Code. It feels I get a peek into the future, and I get why Dario said 6 months ago that 90%
full_text:
Talked with the Claude Code team on how they build Claude Code. It feels I get a peek into the future, and I get why Dario said 6 months ago that 90% of code will be written by AI.

This team works SO differently than any eng team I saw. A few examples:

1. The first code review is always done by Claude (second done by an engineer!)

2. Their test suite is almost 100% written by Claude Code

3. People no longer feel like a jerk by saying on a code review "can you please write a test here" as a result... so nothing goes in without a test. It's so trivial to do vs before.

I also think we might have misinterpreted Dario. He wasn't saying there will be no need for software engineers (at Anthropic, a HUGE need for them, and they are hiring!) 

But these devs work differently: faster, delegating 100% of trivial stuff to Claude, and iterating incredibly quickly, faster than I've seen devs do in the past.

I'll share more next week - I'm writing up what I learned for a deepdive in The Pragmatic Engineer with a lot more details (if you'd like to get it in your inbox when it's out on Tuesday, you can subscribe here: https://lnkd.in/grXSBkVw )

Update: the deepdive is out, here: https://lnkd.in/eBvzDmRK

author: Alex Xu
first_line: MCP vs API: whatâ€™s the difference?
hook_150:
MCP vs API: whatâ€™s the difference?

APIs have been the backbone of software-to-software communication for decades. Now, a new player â€” the Model Conte
full_text:
MCP vs API: whatâ€™s the difference?

APIs have been the backbone of software-to-software communication for decades. Now, a new player â€” the Model Context Protocol (MCP) â€” is emerging as an AI-native protocol designed for agents, IDEs, and LLMs.

API (Application Programming Interface):

- Purpose: Enables software-to-software communication.
- Discovery: Requires documentation.
- Standardization: Varies â€” REST, GraphQL, gRPC, etc.

MCP (Model Context Protocol):

- Purpose: Enables AI-native communication between clients (agents, IDEs, LLMs) and servers.
- Discovery: Self-describing (no external docs needed).
- Standardization: One uniform protocol for resources, tools, and prompts.

Over to you: Do you think MCP will complement APIs or eventually replace them in AI-driven systems?

--
We just launched the all-in-one tech interview prep platform, covering coding, system design, OOD, and machine learning.

Launch sale: 50% off. Check it out: https://lnkd.in/euwKh6u8

#systemdesign #coding #interviewtips

author: Jordan Cutler
first_line: Your manager asks you to delegate more work to other engineers so you can scale yourself. What do yo
hook_150:
Your manager asks you to delegate more work to other engineers so you can scale yourself. What do you do?

Here's the simplest way to remember: think
full_text:
Your manager asks you to delegate more work to other engineers so you can scale yourself. What do you do?

Here's the simplest way to remember: think about each piece of work you delegate like a one-pager.

One-pagers include:
â€¢ Problem
â€¢ Goal
â€¢ Solution
â€¢ Alternatives
â€¢ Risks

Start at the top. Always tell them the problem (or the "why"). Then, continue down the list as far as you'd like, but stop when you're confident the other person can handle the rest.

You can use engineering levels/titles as a rule of thumb, but it doesn't always need to map to that. For example,
â€¢ Staff engineer -> stop at "Problem"
â€¢ Senior engineer -> stop at "Goal"
â€¢ Mid-level engineer -> stop at "Solution"
â€¢ Entry/Junior engineer -> cover most or all

When you want to challenge them, stop earlier. Let them take on more and give them that growth opportunity.

This framework covers what level of detail to provide, but of course, there's more to delegation than that. To get all the details, join 95k+ engineers and check my latest article: https://lnkd.in/ea-JjkKA

author: Gregor Ojstersek
first_line: AI coding tools are not the problem. The problem is accountability.
hook_150:
AI coding tools are not the problem. The problem is accountability.

It's really important to realize that as an engineer, you need to take ownership
full_text:
AI coding tools are not the problem. The problem is accountability.

It's really important to realize that as an engineer, you need to take ownership of your work and not just blindly open PRs without improving and testing the code to fit the guidelines and desired behavior.

Use AI coding tools, but use them to help you, not to do the work instead of you.

Just opening a PR filled with AI-generated slop is a fast way to lose credibility.

author: ğŸŒ€ Luca Rossi
first_line: How do engineering managers create value inside organizations? ğŸ­
hook_150:
How do engineering managers create value inside organizations? ğŸ­

Today I'm publishing an incredible piece by my friend Thiago Ghisi, who spent months
full_text:
How do engineering managers create value inside organizations? ğŸ­

Today I'm publishing an incredible piece by my friend Thiago Ghisi, who spent months researching and creating the most comprehensive framework for EM archetypes I've ever seen.

Most existing models focus on skills or job titles, but those break down quickly. Thiago's approach is different: he identifies *how* managers create leverage, not just what they do. All backed by decades of leadership + psychology research, and 50+ real-world EM case studies.

His model maps managers across two key dimensions:
â†³ ğ—¦ğ˜ğ—®ğ—¯ğ—¶ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ˜ğ˜† ğ˜ƒğ˜€ ğ—–ğ—µğ—®ğ—»ğ—´ğ—² â€” do you optimize systems for steadiness or push them to evolve?â€¨
â†³ ğ—˜ğ˜…ğ—²ğ—°ğ˜‚ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» ğ˜ƒğ˜€ ğ—£ğ—²ğ—¼ğ—½ğ—¹ğ—² â€” do you scale through hard power (delivery) or soft power (culture)?

This creates four foundational archetypes:

â†³ ğŸ§° ğ—¢ğ—½ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¼ğ—¿ (Stability + Execution) â€” the run-the-business managers. Excel at scaling processes, operational rigor, and predictable output.

â†³ ğŸª´ ğ—šğ˜‚ğ—¶ğ—±ğ—² (Stability + People) â€” the grow-the-humans managers. Focus on mentorship, psychological safety, and building strong culture.

â†³ ğŸ ğ——ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¿ (Change + Execution) â€” the fast-delivery managers. Thrive on velocity, ambitious goals, and pushing technical/product boundaries.

â†³ ğŸ”‹ ğ—–ğ—®ğ˜ğ—®ğ—¹ğ˜†ğ˜€ğ˜ (Change + People) â€” the transformation managers. Excel at inspiring teams through vision, reorgs, and cultural shifts.

This would be already incredibly valuable by itself, but Thiago went the extra mile and, for each archetype, he identified both productive and failure patterns: a Driver can be an inspiring "Finisher" or a toxic "Dictator." A Guide can be a nurturing "Mentor" or an enabling "Comforter."

The practical applications are awesome:
â†³ ğ—£ğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—®ğ—¹ ğ—´ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ˜„ğ˜ğ—µ â€” understand your â€œcenter of gravityâ€ and blind spots.â€¨
â†³ ğ—§ğ—²ğ—®ğ—º ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—ºğ—½ğ—¼ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» â€” when staffing your team, balance complementary styles instead of cloning yourself.â€¨
â†³ ğ—›ğ—¶ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ â€” match archetypes to context (e.g. need a crisis manager? get a Driver)
â†³ ğ—£ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—³ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—ºğ—®ğ—»ğ—°ğ—² â€” have precise language for leadership patterns

Thiago even includes AI prompts to help you identify your own archetype using performance reviews and peer feedback!

This is the most useful management framework I've read in years. Full article linked in the comments! ğŸ‘‡

author: Gergely Orosz
first_line: "It's the weirdest job market in my 15 years in tech" -- from a Big Tech recruiter. But why is the j
hook_150:
"It's the weirdest job market in my 15 years in tech" -- from a Big Tech recruiter. But why is the job market so weird? 

Talking to 30+ hiring manage
full_text:
"It's the weirdest job market in my 15 years in tech" -- from a Big Tech recruiter. But why is the job market so weird? 

Talking to 30+ hiring managers and recruiters, it doesn't seem like AI. It seems more like... interest rates.

My longer analysis in today's The Pragmatic Engineer goes into the reasons, as confirmed by those hiring: https://lnkd.in/eeGSFQFQ

author: Nicola Ballotta
first_line: Especially in the IT Engineering field, where competition is high, there's a common misconception th
hook_150:
Especially in the IT Engineering field, where competition is high, there's a common misconception that salary is the only factor that matters.

Of cou
full_text:
Especially in the IT Engineering field, where competition is high, there's a common misconception that salary is the only factor that matters.

Of course, salary is important.

But it's rarely the main driver of retention. Otherwise, everyone would only apply for jobs at FAANG companies.

In reality, for the majority of us in this field, several other key factors make a difference.

ğŸ’° Salary: it's crucial and should align with your competencies, but it doesn't have to be the highest in the market.

ğŸ“š Learning: providing people with a learning budget to use throughout the year is highly appreciated.

ğŸ“ˆ Personal Growth: opportunities for career advancement and skill development matter significantly.

ğŸ›ï¸ Culture: a positive work environment, loving what you do, and enjoying the company of your colleagues are some of the most important aspects.

ğŸ‹ï¸â€â™‚ï¸ Well-Being: mental and physical health has become a priority over the last decade. People value free time to spend with their families or for their hobbies.

Next time, before increasing your employees' salaries (which is fine), as a manager, ensure your team already has access to all of the above.

What other important retention elements have I missed?

â™»ï¸ PLEASE REPOST IF YOU FOUND IT USEFUL, IT MEANS A LOT TO ME.

first_line: I upgraded my Clean Architecture template to .NET 10.
hook_150:
I upgraded my Clean Architecture template to .NET 10.

And it took only a few minutes. Here's how ğŸ‘‡

My .NET version is defined in one place, a Build
full_text:
I upgraded my Clean Architecture template to .NET 10.

And it took only a few minutes. Here's how ğŸ‘‡

My .NET version is defined in one place, a Build props file. I updated to net10 and that took care of all the projects in the solution.

The next part was updating the NuGet packages.

This was equally simple with central package management. I updated the version in the Packages props file, and it was picked up by all the projects in the solution.

Here's what's inside:
- Simple domain model with Domain Events pattern
- CQRS (no MediatR) + clean use cases implementation
- Validation and logging cross-cutting concerns
- Authentication with JWT and user context
- Boilerplate for RBAC authorization
- Docker Compose orchestration
- Minimal APIs, health checks

You can get the template here: https://lnkd.in/eihaFihr

I recently found out my template is used by a local company, doing $30M+ yearly revenue.

author: Jordan Cutler
first_line: The 5 levels of communicating your impact as an engineer in tech:
hook_150:
The 5 levels of communicating your impact as an engineer in tech:

Level 1: What you did
Migrated the user authentication system to OAuth 2.0

Level 2
full_text:
The 5 levels of communicating your impact as an engineer in tech:

Level 1: What you did
Migrated the user authentication system to OAuth 2.0

Level 2: Had impact
...which reduced login failures

Level 3: Specific impact
...by 40% (from 15% to 9%)

Level 4: Tied to a goal
...exceeded our Q2 reliability target by 2x

Level 5: and dollars or top-level business metrics
...and prevented $2.1M in annual revenue loss and saved 15 hours/week in support

If you can include all of these in your self-reviews or resume, it's the strongest impact you can communicate. Still, reaching Level 5 is hard. You might not have all the data to get there, so Level 3-4 is ok too. The key is being as specific as possible with the data you have.

If you found this helpful, you might also like the free custom GPT I created that provides instant tips to improve any impact statement using this framework.

I share the link to it and many more details on communicating impact in the latest High Growth Engineer article. Check it out here! https://lnkd.in/eb27gRDr

full_text:
For the last ~20 years, I did most of my coding inside an IDE - the last ~15 with increasingly good autocomplete.

Which is why itâ€™s so weird that I barely opened an IDE the last two weeks, even as I pushed lots of code. I use the CLI, the web and my phone (!!) to prompt code (with a Claude Code set up via the web integration - and now I can prompt code that pushes to prod via Claude Codeâ€™s mobile app + GH mobile to merge PRs)

When I just started out developing I remember being so so so full of ideas that I was coding in my head and wished I could have done programming while commuting / on the bus. With eg a phone. But it was impossible, ofc.

Now itâ€™s not only possible - but I assume it will become increasingly the norm.

I feel weâ€™re in the middle of the biggest dev tooling change happening across the industry - and itâ€™s happening over a few short months. And rapidly spreading everywhere.

The next months and years weâ€™ll be inventing  and experimenting with new and efficient ways of building software that will be completely normal for new grads entering the industry in a few yearsâ€™ timeâ€¦

What a time to work in tech!

author: Milan JovanoviÄ‡
first_line: .NET 10 is officially released! ğŸ‰
hook_150:
.NET 10 is officially released! ğŸ‰

Here are the top updates ğŸ‘‡

First, .NET 10 is an LTS (long-term support) release. So we get support for the next 3
full_text:
.NET 10 is officially released! ğŸ‰

Here are the top updates ğŸ‘‡

First, .NET 10 is an LTS (long-term support) release. So we get support for the next 3 years.

ğŸ”¥ Performance improvements

Under the hood, .NET 10 delivers major performance boosts. The JIT compiler has been tuned with new optimizations such as deâ€‘abstraction, smarter inlining heuristics and constantâ€‘folding, allowing the runtime to do more work at compileâ€‘time rather than at runâ€‘time. There are many other optimizations across collections and LINQ, which translate to tangible speedups across everyday workloads.

ğŸš€ Aspire goes polyglot

Formerly .NET Aspire, Aspire is now a polyglot, developerâ€‘first platform for orchestrating front ends, APIs, containers and databases. Version 9.5 introduces a preview of a singleâ€‘file AppHost, letting you define and run your entire distributed application in a single file. The release also debuts a Generative AI visualizer to inspect and debug prompts and responses, plus expanded AI support with typed clients for GitHub Models and Azure AI Foundry and firstâ€‘class OpenAI integration.

ğŸ”— EF Coreâ€™s new LeftJoin/RightJoin operators

LINQâ€™s lack of a builtâ€‘in outer join has long been a pain point. EF Core 10 fixes this by adding LeftJoin and RightJoin operators, so the code now reads exactly like the SQL you intend. For example, you can join products to reviews using LeftJoin() and EF will generate the correct LEFT JOIN statement under the hood. A corresponding RightJoin() keeps all rows from the right side while bringing in matches from the left. These new operators eliminate the verbose GroupJoin + DefaultIfEmpty pattern and make LINQ queries easier to read and maintain.

What's your favorite feature coming in .NET 10?

author: Gergely Orosz
first_line: For those saying "English is the new programming language." Here's a thought exercise:
hook_150:
For those saying "English is the new programming language." Here's a thought exercise:

Option A: "Make it dark green
... no, lighter
... no, a bit le
full_text:
For those saying "English is the new programming language." Here's a thought exercise:

Option A: "Make it dark green
... no, lighter
... no, a bit less blueish
... no, a bit more pinkish
... no, a little more greyish
... no, a hint darker"

Option B: use #7DB097

Which option is likely to stick?

"Programming" using English vs a prupose-made language will have the same difference.

It's perfectly possible to write a complex problem by describing what you want to do, to an LLM.

It will probably take 10-100x as much effort compared to a more constrained language with a bunch of rules, built for precise definitions (like a programming language!) Both to create, and especially to modify and maintain your software.

PS: to spell it out, the above is a metaphor. Hex numbers are precise ways to express something that is tricky to do with natural language. Programming languages are similarly precise ways to express what a program to do: far more precise than what a spoken language like English offers.

full_text:
10 Key Data Structures We Use Every DayÂ 
.
.
- list: keep your Twitter feedsÂ 
- stack: support undo/redo of the word editorÂ 
- queue: keep printer jobs, or send user actions in-gameÂ 
- hash table: cashing systemsÂ 
- Array: math operationsÂ 
- heap: task schedulingÂ 
- tree: keep the HTML document, or for AI decisionÂ 
- suffix tree: for searching string in a documentÂ 
- graph: for tracking friendship, or path findingÂ 
- r-tree: for finding the nearest neighborÂ 
- vertex buffer: for sending data to GPU for rendering 

Over to you: Which additional data structures have we overlooked?

author: Milan JovanoviÄ‡
first_line: Did you check out the new IExceptionHandler feature?
hook_150:
Did you check out the new IExceptionHandler feature?

You have to handle exceptions somehow.

IExceptionHandler implements the "try-" pattern.

You ca
full_text:
Did you check out the new IExceptionHandler feature?

You have to handle exceptions somehow.

IExceptionHandler implements the "try-" pattern.

You can decide which exceptions to handle.

To tell the middleware you handled the exception, you return true.

So, what makes this so interesting?

You can also chain multiple exception handlers that will run sequentially.

The first one to handle the exception successfully breaks the chain.

Here's how to use this in .NET 10: https://lnkd.in/e9k5yeJ3

It's a way to compose multiple exception handlers.

How do you approach global error handling?

author: Alex Xu
first_line: Docker vs Kubernetes
hook_150:
Docker vs Kubernetes

Docker is a container platform that lets you package applications with their dependencies and run them on a single machine. Here
full_text:
Docker vs Kubernetes

Docker is a container platform that lets you package applications with their dependencies and run them on a single machine. Hereâ€™s how it works:

1. Starts with the app code and dependencies written into a Dockerfile.
2. The build image step creates a portable container image.
3. A container runtime runs the image directly on the host machine.
4. Networking connects containers and external services and produces the final running app.

Kubernetes is a container orchestration platform that manages containerized applications across a cluster of machines for scalability and resilience. Hereâ€™s how it works:

1. Starts with the app code and dependencies in a Dockerfile.
2. The build image is passed to a container runtime supported by Kubernetes.
3. A master node runs the API server, etcd (key-value store), controller manager, and scheduler to coordinate the cluster.
4. Worker nodes run the actual containers inside the Pods, managed by Kubelet and kube-proxy for networking.
5. Produces a running app that is distributed, scalable, and self-healing in nature.

Over to you: Have you used Docker or Kubernetes in your projects?

--

author: Alex Xu
first_line: Database Types You Should Know in 2025
hook_150:
Database Types You Should Know in 2025

Thereâ€™s no such thing as a one-size-fits-all database anymore. Modern applications rely on multiple database t
full_text:
Database Types You Should Know in 2025

Thereâ€™s no such thing as a one-size-fits-all database anymore. Modern applications rely on multiple database types, from real-time analytics to vector search for AI. Knowing which type to use can make or break your systemâ€™s performance.

Relational: Traditional row-and-column databases, great for structured data and transactions.

Columnar: Optimized for analytics, storing data by columns for fast aggregations.

Key-Value: Stores data as simple keyâ€“value pairs, enabling fast lookups. 

In-memory: Stores data in RAM for ultra-low latency lookups, ideal for caching or session management.

Wide-Column: Handles massive amounts of semi-structured data across distributed nodes.

Time-series: Specialized for metrics, logs, and sensor data with time as a primary dimension.

Immutable Ledger: Ensures tamper-proof, cryptographically verifiable transaction logs.

Graph: Models complex relationships, perfect for social networks and fraud detection

Document: Flexible JSON-like storage, great for modern apps with evolving schemas.

Geospatial: Manages location-aware data such as maps, routes, and spatial queries.

Text-search: Full-text indexing and search with ranking, filters, and analytics.

Blob: Stores unstructured objects like images, videos, and files.

Vector: Powers AI/ML apps by enabling similarity search across embeddings.

Over to you: Which database type do you think will grow fastest in the next 5 years?

--

In his landmark book High Output Management, Andy Grove i
full_text:
Wonder why some team members need more guidance than others? Spoiler: it's not about skill.

In his landmark book High Output Management, Andy Grove introduced the idea of ğ˜ğ—®ğ˜€ğ—¸-ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—¹ğ—²ğ˜ƒğ—®ğ—»ğ˜ ğ—ºğ—®ğ˜ğ˜‚ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ˜ğ˜†, capturing an employee's readiness to shoulder responsibility.

Grove dissects TRM into several factors, but let's focus on the two key ones:

1) ğŸ“ ğ—¦ğ—¸ğ—¶ğ—¹ğ—¹/ğ—™ğ—®ğ—ºğ—¶ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—®ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ˜ğ˜† â€” the employee's expertise and readiness for the task.
2) ğŸ“‹ ğ—–ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜ğ—²ğ˜…ğ˜ ğ—¤ğ˜‚ğ—®ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ˜ğ˜† â€” how robust and well-documented your standards are.

Both items are crucial.

Say you need to create a design doc around a new product feature. You may have the best engineer in the world, who has done hundreds of them in their career, but they still need context from you:

âœ”ï¸ ğ—§ğ—®ğ˜€ğ—¸-ğ˜€ğ—½ğ—²ğ—°ğ—¶ğ—³ğ—¶ğ—° â€” what tradeoffs should they consider? What about speed and scale?

ğŸ”­ ğ—£ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—°ğ—¶ğ—½ğ—¹ğ—²ğ˜€ â€” what do design docs look like on our team? How do you plan rollouts and rollbacks? How is the code instrumented?

The right amount of management depends on the level of TRM:

1) ğŸ”´ ğ—Ÿğ—¼ğ˜„ ğ—§ğ—¥ğ—  â€” your team hasn't done this before, and there's no existing procedure. Provide detailed instructions, pair regularly, and maintain a close feedback loop. Don't let them work too long without your input; correct often and update the procedure with your feedback.

2) ğŸŸ¡ ğ— ğ—²ğ—±ğ—¶ğ˜‚ğ—º ğ—§ğ—¥ğ—  â€” your teammate has completed similar tasks before and knows what good look like, thanks to experience and/or good docs. Provide clear context about the goals, then allow them the freedom to execute.
Keep communication lines open to offer support as needed.

3) ğŸŸ¢ ğ—›ğ—¶ğ—´ğ—µ ğ—§ğ—¥ğ—  â€” your teammate has completed plenty of similar tasks in the past, with good results. In this case, other than giving full autonomy, you can challenge them to improve the definition of good. What can we do better?

â€”â€”

author: Alex Xu
first_line: Evolution of HTTP
hook_150:
Evolution of HTTP

The Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) has evolved over the years to meet the needs of modern applications, from simple text delive
full_text:
Evolution of HTTP

The Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) has evolved over the years to meet the needs of modern applications, from simple text delivery to high-performance, real-time experiences.

Here is how HTTP has progressed:
- HTTP/0.9: Built to fetch simple HTML documents with a single GET request.
- HTTP/1.0: Added headers and status codes to support richer interactions, but every request still required a new connection.
- HTTP/1.1: Introduced persistent connections and more methods, making the web faster and more efficient for everyday browsing.
- HTTP/2: Solved performance bottlenecks with multiplexing, enabling multiple requests to share one connection.
- HTTP/3 (QUIC): Shifted to UDP with QUIC to reduce latency and improve reliability, especially for mobile and real-time apps.

Over to you: Are you already taking advantage of HTTP/3 in your projects?

--

author: Gergely Orosz
first_line: Claude Code is scary good... not just for coding
hook_150:
Claude Code is scary good... not just for coding

My Finder kept freezing after it grew to 8GB in size. I had no idea why. Restarting did not help. Tu
full_text:
Claude Code is scary good... not just for coding

My Finder kept freezing after it grew to 8GB in size. I had no idea why. Restarting did not help. Turning off Spotlight indexing didn't help.

So I turned to Claude Code... and ~10 iterations+30 minutes later it found the issue, and helped fix it. It ran diagnostics commands to map memory usage, scanned the filesystem, looked at the size of nested directories, experimented moving folders with large files from know indexing locations to see if helped then killed the process and monitored to see if it helped (it did not) and then got to this approach.

This kind of debugging - where an agent can execute commands, get their output, and change their next step after - simply did not exist before an AI agent like Claude Code (and similar ones)

It's a brand new capability... and if you can do this, what else can you do? Just food for thought how good these tools are getting, quickly!

(As context, I didn't "let the LLM run wild, and one reason it took so long is I double checked each command before letting it run, and after a while allowed *read* commands to run without it asking me. Claude Code has a well-designed permissions system - covered more in this deepdive talking with the Claude Code team: https://lnkd.in/e2Hbuy8S)

Top 5 Software Architectural Patterns

In software development, architecture plays a crucial role in shaping the structure and behavior of software sy
full_text:
Top 5 Software Architectural Patterns

In software development, architecture plays a crucial role in shaping the structure and behavior of software systems. It provides a blueprint for system design, detailing how components interact with each other to deliver specific functionality. They also offer solutions to common problems, saving time and effort and leading to more robust and maintainable systems.

However, with the vast array of architectural styles and patterns available, it can take time to discern which approach best suits a particular project or system. Aims to shed light on these concepts, helping you make informed decisions in your architectural endeavors.

To help you navigate the vast landscape of architectural styles and patterns, there is a cheat sheet that encapsulates all. This cheat sheet is a handy reference guide that you can use to quickly recall the main characteristics of each architectural style and pattern.

author: ğŸŒ€ Luca Rossi
first_line: Engineers are quietly replacing the IDE with the terminal
hook_150:
Engineers are quietly replacing the IDE with the terminal

Six months ago, every serious â€œAI coderâ€ I knew was using Cursor, while today most of them
full_text:
Engineers are quietly replacing the IDE with the terminal

Six months ago, every serious â€œAI coderâ€ I knew was using Cursor, while today most of them have shifted to Claude Code or some other CLI tool.

How is that possible?! We have been working inside IDEs for 20+ years! I talked with a lot of engineers and here is my interpretation of it:

Traditional coding splits ~80/20 between writing code and running commands (build, run, test, etc). IDEs optimize for that first 80%â€”the actual code writing.

But AI is flipping this ratio. We're writing less code by hand, but we still need to run and check stuff. So the terminal becomes more important.

Also, IDEs give you classic "engineer context" â€” file trees, text editor, syntax highlighting, etc, while CLI tools give you "manager context"â€”what's the plan, what commands are running, what are the outputs. AI tools are good enough now that we probably need to default to manager mode, not engineer mode. It feels funny to say it, but: donâ€™t micromanage AI!

If I look at the best AI coders I know these aren't the best traditional developers. They are first and foremost good managersâ€”they work in small batches, provide good context, and jump in only when needed.

That's probably the way to go (and always has been?!)

author: ğŸŒ€ Luca Rossi
first_line: The best article I have read this week is "The Profitable Startup" by Karri Saarinen at Linear.
hook_150:
The best article I have read this week is "The Profitable Startup" by Karri Saarinen at Linear.

You can easily measure the quality of a piece by the
full_text:
The best article I have read this week is "The Profitable Startup" by Karri Saarinen at Linear.

You can easily measure the quality of a piece by the density of highlights you take. So here are a few of my own:

â†³ "I don't know why hiring massive teams ever became the norm. In my own experience, small teams always delivered better quality, and faster."

â†³ "What holds you back is rarely team size â€“ it's the clarity of your focus, skill and ability to execute."

â†³ "For most software startups, ten people before product-market fit should be your ceiling, not your target."

â†³ "After PMF, every hire should address a specific, pressing need â€“ not just fill out an org chart."

â€”

The main thesis here is that today profitability has become easier to reach, especially if you work in a space where there is already a market (you have competition), and no big investments are needed upfront.

Profitability is also a good north star that drives good behavior: focus on business value, donâ€™t over hire, keep talking with customers, and so on.

I like how it feels like the tide is shifting a bit on this. With the (glaring) exception of glorious AI slop startups, it feels like there is a growing sub-culture of small to mid-size companies shipping top quality products, and creating good, sustainable culture in the process.

There is something beautiful about this â€œlong-tail innovationâ€, and I hope to keep doing my small part in helping people who work on it ğŸ˜Š

Here is Karri's piece: https://lnkd.in/d4h5uP3P

author: ğŸŒ€ Luca Rossi
first_line: Is it possible to vibe-code production apps into existence? This question is everywhere on my feed.
hook_150:
Is it possible to vibe-code production apps into existence? This question is everywhere on my feed. 

Based on everything I tried myself + the apps I
full_text:
Is it possible to vibe-code production apps into existence? This question is everywhere on my feed. 

Based on everything I tried myself + the apps I have seen + the people I talked with, here is my take:

1) If you are a non-technical person: 100% impossible. Tools get stuck pretty soon. They also get unstuck equally fast if pointed to the right direction, but you are not equipped with the skills to help them do so.

2) If you are an engineer, the definition of vibe coding gets tricky. AI may write 99% of the code, but you may still have a lot of input on system design, requirements, bug fixing, etc. So you are technically not writing almost any code, but you are in the loop of how things are getting done.

In this second version of vibe coding, it is 100% possible to deliver functioning, revenue-generating apps. 

But, I suspect, this is not the use case most people (and VCs) get excited about. It looks, to me, like an updated version of the low/no code tools movement: they, too, promised to give non techies the ability to create apps, but for the most part only made engineers more productive.

Finally, someone wrote it down in a book:

To understand what is going well/poorly inside your engineering org: ask the devs what this is! Talk to a bunch of them - from different teams, seniority levels etc - and understand what's really going on.

From the excellent new book by Nicole Forsgren and Abi Noda called "Frictionless"

Arrived yesterday. So far a very timely read.

The book attempts to answer the question: "AI can generate code in minutes - so why does shipping software still take forever?"

It's a very timely one. As with Accelerate, I think this might also become a classic

full_text:
Ironic: as LLMs make writing much easier, I am finding not more, but less interesting and novel things to read online.

And so I keep paying more attention to the fewer people who still write their original thoughts (without LLMs - you can tell how repetitive / pattern matching it gets with them, including on LinkedIn.)

By â€œinteresting thingsâ€ I mean when people share their own experiences, connecting the dots, own speculation/analysis etc.

Eg learnings they had on stuff they recently did, and so on.

Anyway, power to those who didnâ€™t forget writing helps you think and reflect as well!

Examples of people who I keep paying attention to thanks to writing about their experiences: Simon Willison and Sean Goedecke on their respective blogs, where they publish regularly: https://simonwillison.net/ and https://lnkd.in/dk7Ywgxm

full_text:
Cloudflare is much more than just a CDN and DDoS protection service.

Letâ€™s do a quick comparison of Cloudflare, AWS, and Azure.

Cloudflare has rapidly expanded beyond its traditional CDN roots, launching a suite of modern developer-first services like Workers, R2, D1, and so on. These offerings position it as a serious edge-native alternative to other cloud providers.

Here are the key cloud capabilities that Cloudflare supports:

1 - Edge Compute and Serverless
2 - Object and Blob Storage
3 - Relational Databases
4 - Containers
5 - Sandboxes
6 - Workflows
7 - AI Agents SDK
8 - Vector and AI search
9 - Data Connectivity
10 - AI Infrastructure
11 - Content Delivery Network
12 - DNS
13 - Load Balancing

Over to you: Have you used Cloudflareâ€™s new offerings? What are your thoughts on them?

full_text:
I am back in Rome after spending two days in London for LDX3 â€” and what a high it was!

I have many *work friends* on the internet, but I rarely get to see them face to face. In fact, I spend most of my days alone in my *cave* writing newsletter articles ğŸ˜„

So it was incredible to meet so many of them all in the same place â€” and most of them for the first time.Â Shout-outs to Camille, Laura, Patrick, Lena (we literally bumped into each other in the elevator), Maria, Claire, Gergely, and all the others I met who I am inevitably forgetting, for making these days special.Â  

A special shout-out to Charity, who made me incredibly happy by bringing on stage â€œIn Praise of Normal Engineersâ€ â€” the article she published on Refactoring. She did an amazing job (linking it in the comments in case you missed it) and it was just the perfect way to close the event!

Also, to comply with my duties as a writer, I took *a ton* of notes during the event, and I will publish a write-up with the ideas I liked the most in the next week or so!

Finally, a big thank you to Mariana, Penny, Meri, and all the folks at LeadDev who made this possible. It was my first time at a Leaddev conference and everything was a blast: from the level of the talks, to the atmosphere, to the overall organization. 

Looking forward to the next one!

System Design Newsletter by Neo Kim: https://lnkd.in/epCMRzyX (Learn system design in 5 minutes or less from real company stories.)

Scarlet Ink by David Anderson: https://lnkd.in/etbTHEjy (Former Amazon Exec gives fantastic personal stories and examples on growth in tech)

Eczachly Data Engineering Newsletter by Zach Wilson: https://lnkd.in/ejC7bgVK (Interview better, learn how to get promoted quickly, and become better at data engineering)

Coding Challenges by John Crickett: https://lnkd.in/et9b6VDQ (Level up through real-world coding challenges)

author: Jordan Cutler
first_line: After landing a $350k offer in big tech, my friend quoted this interview tip as what helped him the
hook_150:
After landing a $350k offer in big tech, my friend quoted this interview tip as what helped him the most in landing the job.

Don't answer the questio
full_text:
After landing a $350k offer in big tech, my friend quoted this interview tip as what helped him the most in landing the job.

Don't answer the question. Answer the question BEHIND the question.

Here's an example:

â€¢ Interviewer asks... "Tell me about your biggest failure"
â€¢ You respond by telling them about a big project that didn't ship on time and everyone moved on. That feels like a failure, right?

The problem is, the question behind the question was, "How well do you learn from your big failures?" So you can still tell the story about your biggest failure, but you need to touch on what you learned from it! Every answer you give uncovers more to the interviewer about how you are to work with (the pie below).

Here are some more examples:
â€¢ Biggest disagreement -> Can you work with others? (not a chance to brag about swapping teams due to arguments)
â€¢ A project you are proud of -> How large is your scope and do you approach projects methodically?
â€¢ A time when you missed a deadline -> Do you let others know ahead of time when your estimate is off? How do you approach your relationship with stakeholders?

Each question has something underlying the interviewer is trying to get at.

Figure out what it is. Answer THAT question and you'll see the offers start coming in.

--
The thing is, this framework isn't just useful for interviews. You can use it when you're fielding questions during a presentation, or when you're dealing with hard questions from your manager on why something hasn't shipped.

To see how AND learn 4 other top communication frameworks like this one, click the link next to my profile picture.

Tomorrow's High Growth Engineer issue will feature some of Wes Kao's most valuable frameworks engineers can use every day.

author: Alex Xu
first_line: HTTP vs. HTTPS
hook_150:
HTTP vs. HTTPS

When you open a website, the difference between HTTP and HTTPS decides whether your data travels safely or in plain sight. Hereâ€™s what
full_text:
HTTP vs. HTTPS

When you open a website, the difference between HTTP and HTTPS decides whether your data travels safely or in plain sight. Hereâ€™s what actually happens under the hood:

HTTP:
- Sends data in plain text, anyone on the network can intercept it.
- The client and server perform a simple TCP handshake: SYN, SYN-ACK, ACK
- Fast but completely insecure. Passwords, tokens, and forms can all be read in transit.

HTTPS (SSL/TLS):
- Step 1: TCP Handshake: Standard connection setup.
- Step 2: Certificate Check: Client says hello. Server responds with hello and its SSL/TLS certificate. That certificate contains the server's public key and is signed by a trusted Certificate Authority. 

Your browser verifies this certificate is legitimate, not expired, and actually belongs to the domain you're trying to reach. This proves you're talking to the real server, not some attacker pretending to be it.

- Step 3: Key Exchange: Here's where asymmetric encryption happens. The server has a public key and a private key. Client generates a session key, encrypts it with the server's public key, and sends it over. Only the server can decrypt this with its private key.

Both sides now have the same session key that nobody else could have intercepted. This becomes the symmetric encryption key for the rest of the session.

- Step 4: Data Transmission: Now every request and response gets encrypted with that session key using symmetric encryption.

Over to you: Whatâ€™s your go-to tool for debugging TLS issues, openssl, curl -v, or something else?

--

author: Gergely Orosz
first_line: So Linear has a 30-minute weekly meeting called "Quality Wednesdays." I sat through the last one: ju
hook_150:
So Linear has a 30-minute weekly meeting called "Quality Wednesdays." I sat through the last one: just WOW

We went through 17 issues, from massive ba
full_text:
So Linear has a 30-minute weekly meeting called "Quality Wednesdays." I sat through the last one: just WOW

We went through 17 issues, from massive backend performance wins, to this tiny one, on the image below. Can you see the issue that needed to be fixed?

It was both super casual... devs could really show *anything* that improves the quality or performance of Linear that they fixed. Most devs showed one or two small things. This off-by-one pixel was both found and fixed by Axel Niklasson Yun. Hawk eyes!

It felt like boom-boom-boom-boom. Small fix, neat fix, massive fix, usability fix. The next dev birefly showed what the problem was before, how it's fixed now, and a short summary of what they did, and how they measured it (for performance fixes like rendering times, or resource usage for backend improvements) 

There were some more involved parts, but no time wasted. For example, Kenneth Skovhus spent a few minutes showing how because styled-components *feels* slow, they tried out 3 other frameworks & measured how they compare for build time, JS bundle size, CSS size, and LCP rendering performance.  Based on this, they'll probably move off styled components... mainly for LCP rendering for massive pages to be faster. But it's all tradeoffs. (He actually wrote more about it here: https://lnkd.in/eYTc_m6i)

Or Maciek PÄ™kala showed his fix where for  massive documents when you pressed Tab+F (to search) it took seconds for the search tab to appear because the DOM TreeWalker blocked the UI thread. He made a fix to make it yield, and there are no delays now.

Midway, unexpected (to me!) cofounder and CTO Tuomas Artman also showed his fix for the week. Love seeing hands-on founders, and this is definitely the case at Linear.

The full session was full of energy... pure joy! In the end, we overran by 8 minutes, truth be told, but it was so dense that I don't think anyone minded.

Linear definitely has a unique engineering culture. I previously did a deepdive on this in The Pragmatic Engineer which was paywalled - but now the paywall is removed. If you're interested in how they work, check it out: https://lnkd.in/eqxyrh4M

And if you're building a product, consider doing something like this. Users will be grateful, and as an engineer it's satisfying to fix things!

first_line: 24 Good Resources to Learn Software Architecture in 2025
hook_150:
24 Good Resources to Learn Software Architecture in 2025

The resources can be divided into different types such as:

1 - Software Design Books
Some b
full_text:
24 Good Resources to Learn Software Architecture in 2025

The resources can be divided into different types such as:

1 - Software Design Books
Some books that can help are DDIA, System Design Volume 1 & 2, Clean Architecture, Domain-Driven Design, and Software Architecture: the Hard Parts

2 - Tech Blogs and Newsletters
Read technical blogs by companies like Netflix, Uber, Meta, and Airbnb. Also, the ByteByteGo newsletter provides insights into software design every week.

3 - YouTube Channels and Architectural Resources
YouTube channels like MIT Distributed Systems, Goto Conferences, and ByteByteGo can help with software architecture and system design. Azure Architecture Center and AWS Architecture Blog are other important resources.

4 - WhitePapers
For deeper insights, read whitepapers like Facebook Memcache Scaling, Cassandra, Amazon DynamoDB, Kafka, and Google File System.

5 - Software Career Books
A Software Architect also needs to develop holistic skills. Books about software career aspects such as Pragmatic Programmer, The Software Architect Elevator, The Software Engineer's Guidebook, and Philosophy of Software Design can help.

Over to you: Which other resources will you add to the list?

--

author: Nicola Ballotta
first_line: As an Engineering Leader, there's one thing you have to carefully watch out for within your teams.
hook_150:
As an Engineering Leader, there's one thing you have to carefully watch out for within your teams.


ğŸš« Over-Engineering.

Engineers often aim for perf
full_text:
As an Engineering Leader, there's one thing you have to carefully watch out for within your teams.


ğŸš« Over-Engineering.

Engineers often aim for perfection.

On one hand, this is good because it means they care and don't want to deliver crappy solutions. On the other hand, there's always the risk that they might focus on things that are not necessary from the beginning.

This is also why you want to foster a product-oriented mindset among your engineers.

ğŸš€ When you have to launch a new product, you don't need to think about scaling it to 10 million users from the beginning, providing a 99.999% Uptime SLA, or building it on 20 microservices.

The first thing a product needs is validation, and you want it to happen sooner rather than later.

For this reason, it's important to:

ğŸ”¥ Focus on delivering an MVP. This doesn't mean delivering low quality, but focusing on making the product ready for 100 or 1000 customers, not 10M.

â™»ï¸ Invest in a robust CI/CD system. This will facilitate faster iterations on the product, enabling you to improve the product and fix bugs more rapidly.

ğŸ—ï¸ Keep the architecture simple. While microservices are powerful for large teams and complex architectures (although not a strict rule), they are  also challenging to manage and coordinate.

ğŸ—£ï¸ Involve your team in product discussions. This will help them understand why certain decisions are made and why perfection isn't expected right from the beginning.

What else?

â™»ï¸ PLEASE REPOST IF YOU FOUND IT USEFUL, IT MEANS A LOT TO ME.

---

author: Alex Xu
first_line: Apache Kafka vs. RabbitMQ
hook_150:
Apache Kafka vs. RabbitMQ

Kafka and RabbitMQ both handle messages, but they solve fundamentally different problems. Understanding the difference matt
full_text:
Apache Kafka vs. RabbitMQ

Kafka and RabbitMQ both handle messages, but they solve fundamentally different problems. Understanding the difference matters when designing distributed systems.

Kafka is a distributed log. Producers append messages to partitions. Those messages stick around based on retention policy, not because someone consumed them. Consumers pull messages at their own pace using offsets. You can rewind, replay, reprocess everything. It is designed for high throughput event streaming where multiple consumers need the same data independently.

RabbitMQ is a message broker. Producers publish messages to exchanges. Those exchanges route to queues based on binding keys and patterns (direct, topic, fanout). Messages get pushed to consumers and then deleted once acknowledged. It is built for task distribution and traditional messaging workflows.

The common mistake is using Kafka like a queue or RabbitMQ like an event log. They're different tools built for different use cases.

Over to you:  If you had to explain when NOT to use Kafka, what would you say?

--

full_text:
I'm not a great reader, but there's one book I've been reading for the third year in a row that you should check out.


ğŸš€ ğ—”ğ˜ğ—¼ğ—ºğ—¶ğ—° ğ—›ğ—®ğ—¯ğ—¶ğ˜ğ˜€.

One of the most important concepts in the book is the "Plateau of Latent Potential," which, in simple terms, is the time that elapses between when we start doing something and when we actually see results.

We often expect this duration to be linear and assume that as soon as we start doing something, we should immediately see some small results. Unfortunately, it doesn't work that way, and this mismatch can lead to disappointment, which often results in giving up.

The reality is that you usually begin to see progress just when you've passed a certain critical threshold, and then it becomes exponential.

ğŸŒ€ Think about when you want to introduce a change in your team, even a small one, or when you want to learn something new. Instead of focusing on the results, be consistent in what you want to achieve, not just for days or weeks, but at least for a few months. Eventually, the results will come, and they will be exponential.

I'm impatient by nature, but this book literally changed my life and how I perceive change and progress.

ğ—•ğ—²ğ—³ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—² ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—®ğ—±ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—¶ğ˜:

ğŸš§ I started many things and eventually abandoned them after a few weeks or months.

ğŸ“ I was measuring my progress every single day, without actually seeing any progress.

ğŸ˜ I felt frustrated and sometimes doubted my intelligence to accomplish things.

ğ—”ğ—³ğ˜ğ—²ğ—¿ ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—®ğ—±ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—¶ğ˜:

ğŸŒŸ  I'm still impatient, but I stick with the things that really matter to me.

â±ï¸ I stopped measuring my progress every day; now, I look at my progress each month.

ğŸŒ¤ï¸ Sometimes I still feel frustrated, but when I do, it's because I know I wasn't consistent enough in my efforts.

Did you read this book? How it impacted your life?

author: Gergely Orosz
first_line: Another 4 months and this will be my longest-held job (#1 is my tenure at Uber till then)
hook_150:
Another 4 months and this will be my longest-held job (#1 is my tenure at Uber till then)

Comes to show how hard it's predict your career. If you had
full_text:
Another 4 months and this will be my longest-held job (#1 is my tenure at Uber till then)

Comes to show how hard it's predict your career. If you had asked me 5 years ago (when I left Uber) where I see myself in 5 years, I would have listed likely possibilities as:

1. Startup founder or CTO (that was my original plan when leaving Uber!)

2. Back at Big Tech as an engineer or EM 

... writing/researching full-time was not on my bingo list! It's the "job" I never thought I'd do, and especially not that so many people would follow along. And yet, it's the best "job" I've had so far - one that doesn't feel like a "job!"

Of course, I couldn't do it without everyone who reads (or listens to) The Pragmatic Engineer and everyone helping with input, observations, and criticism as well - thank you.

Here's to many more years to come with The Pragmatic Engineer!

(I'm writing this in the middle of summarizing all that we've researched about Google's engineering cutlure with Elin Nilsson, after talking with 20+ current and past engineers at Google, spread over 6 months. It's more extensive - and more exciting! - than covered anywhere before, and is coming out tomorrow - you can get it in your inbox by subscribing at https://lnkd.in/grXSBkVw). This is what I mean about work that doesn't feel like "work" - because it's so interesting!

Put yourself in others' shoes.

Our industry is scarce on people who really
full_text:
As an Engineer, Empathy will do more for your career than beautiful code.

Put yourself in others' shoes.

Our industry is scarce on people who really listen to others, who are generous and understanding.

An abundance of empathy will lead you to an abundant career.

author: Jordan Cutler
first_line: 6 Must Have Software Engineering Templates to grow as an engineer:
hook_150:
6 Must Have Software Engineering Templates to grow as an engineer:

This week I covered 6 of the templates I use the most as Senior Engineer in Big Te
full_text:
6 Must Have Software Engineering Templates to grow as an engineer:

This week I covered 6 of the templates I use the most as Senior Engineer in Big Tech. Here they are, with links to each one!

1. Technical Design Doc Template: https://lnkd.in/enamp3FW

Use this when your team already agreed you'll work on something, and now you need to sort out "how" you're going to build it and what milestones.

2. Feedback Template: https://lnkd.in/ehsuJUkk

Use this to give feedback in a non-judgmental, constructive way to help the other person improve.

3. 1-Pager Proposal Template: https://lnkd.in/eCXRcg-W

Use this when you need to focus more on the "why" than the "how." It lets you propose an idea to actually get it prioritized.

4. Pull Request Template: https://lnkd.in/et6DTYfv

Use this to clearly describe your changes and get faster reviews by making your reviewers' lives easier.

5. 1-on-1 Template: https://lnkd.in/eg6NcHbe

Use this for more productive for 1:1s and to avoid getting sidetracked.

6. Brag Doc + Weekly Update Template: https://lnkd.in/eFbMgbb7

Use this to track your accomplishments and update your manager on your plan + what you did for the week.

What templates did I miss? I'm happy to cover and add them to our template library!

To see the full post covering each of these templates in detail, join 85k engineers and check it out here: https://lnkd.in/e8tM6RGt

author: Thiago Ghisi
first_line: Iâ€™ve delivered 100+ large features over last 10+ years as an Engineer/Manager/Director, here is a le
hook_150: Iâ€™ve delivered 100+ large features over last 10+ years as an Engineer/Manager/Director, here is a lesson I learned 3 years ago that completely changed
full_text:
Iâ€™ve delivered 100+ large features over last 10+ years as an Engineer/Manager/Director, here is a lesson I learned 3 years ago that completely changed the game:

> A bad & unclear decision (yet intentional) is better than no decision in 99% of cases.

This might seem extreme/unproductive, but isnâ€™t.

Without a larger plan, there are some technical decisions you just canâ€™t make decisively. 

â€”> Are you all aiming for Future State A or Future State B? 

Teams often hedge and avoid making the small decisions because they donâ€™t know what the big ones will be.

Not making a decision might end up being worse than any of the decisions on the table would have been. 

This especially shows up with architectural decisions, where teams donâ€™t commit to one approach or another, and end up trying to be flexible enough to support both.

It is better to make a "bad & wrong decision" today (and fail/revisit and improve later) than no decision today and tomorrow with the "illusion" that a perfect decision or solution will appear tomorrow.

In my experience, most projects fail or get delayed not because developers are slow, but because the analysis paralysis of over-engineering that slows down the decisions that the team, the department or the company has to make to move things forward even when they donâ€™t have all the info.

And, in my experience, when you have an aggressive deadline or release target (as it was almost always the case for me and my teams in those high-performing/hyper-growth companies), you will never have all the info you need. Or, when you have that, it will be way too late.

Practice: 24-Hour Decision Making.

Promoting the idea that making a decision & iterating on it even when there is some disagreement is better for the team in the long-term than spending a lot of time trying to local optimize a decision with a lot of unproductive discussions.

Having a winner or a losser in a discussion/decision is less important to us than moving forward and iterating on things as a team and getting real feedback from users (it could be even internal/alpha users) from the production environment (it could be from the staging in some cases as well) after have gone full cycle (from requirements to deployment) and end-to-end (from database to UX).

On Slack Threads that go wild for a few hours or Pull Requests that get stuck for more than 1 day:

Here is how we did it:

Thread in m1-us-payments-v2

> thiagoghisi: 

â±24-Hour Decision Pending starting now: 

> Sep 22 at 3pm EST:

> Question to be answered: How do we want to handle Back Navigation on Global Payments for Radio Selectors as Payment Amount, Payment Date & Bank Account?

------ after a sync ------

> Sep 23 at 330pm EST:

â±Time to decision: 24 hours and 30 minutes.

> Decision: Make tapping on back button after selecting Payment Date, Payment Amount & Bank Account will be required for both iOS and Android for all cases. cc/ ...

> Link to ADR: ...

author: ğŸŒ€ Luca Rossi
first_line: Yesterday, I had an interesting conversation with my wife about AI.
hook_150:
Yesterday, I had an interesting conversation with my wife about AI.

My wife is a radiologist, which is one of the hottest spaces where AI is believed
full_text:
Yesterday, I had an interesting conversation with my wife about AI.

My wife is a radiologist, which is one of the hottest spaces where AI is believed to make an impact, but she argued that AI is *never* going to save her time.

At first I thought she was nuts â€” but she had a great point instead.

She argued that even if they had *perfect* AI to create examination reports, they would obviously use it only to create *drafts*, to be later verified by doctors. And the thing is, verifying the draft of a report takes roughly the same time as doing it from scratch, because you have to go through all the examination data and images again to see if AI has missed something. 

So, unless at some point we decide to accept AI output as-is, without human verificationâ€”which seems highly unlikelyâ€”this is an inescapable problem. AI can help doctors create higher-quality work, but it will not save a lot of time.

This made me think that there are two classes of activities: the ones where verifying correctness takes significantly less time than doing the actual thingâ€”letâ€™s call them *verifiable*â€” and the ones where verification is comparable to the full executionâ€”letâ€™s call them *unverifiable*.

(not a big fan of these names, can you think of better alternatives?)

So, in software, coding is a verifiable activity: itâ€™s (usually?!) way easier to verify correctness of software than writing it from scratch.

But code reviews, for example, are unverifiable: checking that an AI code review hasnâ€™t missed anything requires you to go through the code yourself. Taking meeting notes is another obviously unverifiable task.

This is relevant because, for example, as AI makes us write faster code, we need to be able to review it just as fast to keep up with it â€” but AI code reviews are not going to save us significant time unless we accept them without verification, which means giving up some control over the code.

What does this mean for the future? I should write a conclusion but for now I donâ€™t have any ğŸ™‚

These were just some morning thoughts â˜€ï¸

Have a good start of the week!

author: Gergely Orosz
first_line: I'm telling you: GitHub's biggest competitor could soon be Cursor. One hint: Cursor just acquired Gr
hook_150: I'm telling you: GitHub's biggest competitor could soon be Cursor. One hint: Cursor just acquired Graphite. Cursor is playing chess, everyone else is
full_text:
I'm telling you: GitHub's biggest competitor could soon be Cursor. One hint: Cursor just acquired Graphite. Cursor is playing chess, everyone else is busy with checkers:

Graphite - in my view! - is the best AI code review + stacked diffs + PR workflow product out there (disclaimer: I am [was?] an investor in Graphite - details here: https://lnkd.in/e98J2Bbu). Stacked diffs are an incredibly efficient way to work faster, preferred in larger teams and orgs, which I covered more in this The Pragmatic Engineer deepdive (probably the most quoted one on the topic:) https://lnkd.in/eQXRVmp7

GitHub is already playing catchup to Cursor/Graphite: they will be adding stacked diffs in 2026, years after Graphite has polished this. 

And looking to the future: I am less and less confident that git will be the preferred way to store source code. Git doesn't support metadata like agent trajectories (that are increasingly important to attach to PRs), and was built to satisfy the workflow of Linux kernel development, and not working with AI agents.

If and when a new standard starts to spread: you can bet that Cursor will be natively supporting it - or perhaps they'll create whatever this will be!

author: Alex Xu
first_line: 12 Architectural Concepts Developers Should Know
hook_150:
12 Architectural Concepts Developers Should Know

1 - Load Balancing: Distributed incoming traffic across multiple servers to ensure no single node is
full_text:
12 Architectural Concepts Developers Should Know

1 - Load Balancing: Distributed incoming traffic across multiple servers to ensure no single node is overwhelmed.
2 - Caching: Stores frequently accessed data in memory to reduce latency.
3 - Content Delivery Network (CDN): Stores static assets across geographically distributed edge servers so users download content from the nearest location.
4 - Message Queue: Decouples components by letting producers enqueue messages that consumers process asynchronously.
5 - Publish-Subscribe: Enables multiple consumers to receive messages from a topic.
6 - API Gateway: Acts as a single entry point for client requests, handling routing, authentication, rate limiting, and protocol translation.
7 - Circuit Breaker: Monitors downstream service calls and stops attempts when failures exceed a threshold.
8 - Service Discovery: Automatically tracks available service instances so components can locate and communicate with each other dynamically.
9 - Sharding: Splits large datasets across multiple nodes based on a specific shard key.
10 - Rate Limiting: Controls the number of requests a client can make in a given time window to protect services from overload.
11 - Consistent Hashing: Distributes data across nodes in a way that minimizes reorganization when nodes join or leave.
12 - Auto Scaling: Automatically adds or removes compute resources based on defined metrics.

Over to you: Which architectural concept will you add to the list?

--

We, managers, are back to coding! Is this a good thing?

One of the biggest stories I have been hearing recently is that many engineering managers are
full_text:
We, managers, are back to coding! Is this a good thing?

One of the biggest stories I have been hearing recently is that many engineering managers are back to coding, because of AI. 

AI is helping in two ways:

â†³ ğŸ§  ğ—œğ˜ ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—±ğ˜‚ğ—°ğ—²ğ˜€ ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—´ğ—»ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—¶ğ˜ƒğ—² ğ—¹ğ—¼ğ—®ğ—±Â â€” managers often retain good taste for what good code looks like, but are a bit rusty on implementation details. AI makes the latter less relevant.

â†³ ğŸ—“ï¸ ğ—œğ˜ ğ—³ğ—¶ğ˜ğ˜€ ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—±ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—¶ğ—»ğ˜ğ—¼ ğ—½ğ—®ğ—°ğ—¸ğ—²ğ—± ğ—®ğ—´ğ—²ğ—»ğ—±ğ—®ğ˜€Â â€” by letting terminal agents run while people are on meetings or doing something else.

Is this a good thing? A reader told me "Managers need to focus on the things that only they can do, rather than the things that anyone on their team can do."

This is not wrong, but I also think many managers end up completely detached from how their team works, and spending some time coding can help *a lot*. 

The benefit here is not about throughput, but about empathy and staying in touch with what the DX and the whole process looks like.

This is most definitely good and I would love to see more of it.

Have a good week! â˜€ï¸

author: Louie Bacaj
first_line: I used to explain to C-Level execs:
hook_150:
I used to explain to C-Level execs: 

Software built by competent engineering teams actually benefits from disorder and chaos.

To these teams, bugs c
full_text:
I used to explain to C-Level execs: 

Software built by competent engineering teams actually benefits from disorder and chaos.

To these teams, bugs can be good.

When a bug is found, they not only fix the bug in question but make it so that entire class of bugs never occur again.

Competent engineering teams build antifragile systems.

Systems that actually improve from defects.

Incompetent teams suffer from the same types of bugs over and over.

author: Gergely Orosz
first_line: The positive thing about AI tooling going mainstream and setting expectations high (e.g. "anyone can
hook_150: The positive thing about AI tooling going mainstream and setting expectations high (e.g. "anyone can build software with AI") is that a large group wi
full_text:
The positive thing about AI tooling going mainstream and setting expectations high (e.g. "anyone can build software with AI") is that a large group will learn what us devs know already:

Creating good software is hard and it's hard to explain to outsiders in a way they understand.

We have millions of non-technical ppl believe that they are equipped to create software that works as they imagined, using AI + vibe coding

...only to crash and burn.

They are now not outsiders, and might be open to understand why software is hard (and how they can get better)

As to why building good software is hard: where do I start?

Because:

- Good software solves a problem people/customers have

- Good software has users and customers

- Good software is not always good code, and good code is not always good software

- Craft and commercial viability are not always connected

- Tech debt is hard to appreciate from the outside, but you feel it every day in the inside

- After a while, code is the trivial part, and everything else (people, the business, politics etc) become the hard parts

... and many, many more things.

If you ever worked as a developer at any company on a software product, you get to learn so many things that are counter-intuitive from the "outside."

And don't forget that "good software" is very different for a startup looking for product-market fit, a scaleup that found it and needs to grow rapidly, or a stable and mature business that prioritizes keeping existing customers happy vs getting new ones.

Building good software has always been hard, but rewarding when you get it right. I don't think AI changes this - in fact, these tools can create the illusion that it's now easier than before to create it.

first_line: Differences between the Team Lead and the Tech Lead roles.
hook_150:
Differences between the Team Lead and the Tech Lead roles.

Team Lead:
- Normally has direct reports
- Facilitates team meetings
- Coaching, mentoring
full_text:
Differences between the Team Lead and the Tech Lead roles.

Team Lead:
- Normally has direct reports
- Facilitates team meetings
- Coaching, mentoring, and delegating work

I like to view this role as doing whatâ€™s best for the team -> If the team lacks technical seniority, you need to fill this gap, and if the team is drowning in tasks, you focus on better prioritization, stakeholder management, or help with finishing the tasks. Itâ€™s certainly a role for good generalists.

Tech Lead:
- Doesn't have direct reports
- Responsible for the technical implementation of the specific project
- Coaching, mentoring, planning, stakeholder management

I like to view this role as a good mix of technical and people-related skills, which includes: common sense and pragmatism, good communication and leadership, being a multiplier for others, and making everyone around them better.

To learn about all the differences between the lead roles, I have just sent out the newsletter to 179k+ engineering leaders called: "Differences Between Lead Roles and How to Find Your Right Path".

author: Milan JovanoviÄ‡
first_line: I failed an interview because I didn't know how locks work in C#.
hook_150:
I failed an interview because I didn't know how locks work in C#.

Read this to make sure it never happens to you.

I've told this story a couple of t
full_text:
I failed an interview because I didn't know how locks work in C#.

Read this to make sure it never happens to you.

I've told this story a couple of times before, but it's worth repeating.

I was in an interview some 7-8 years ago, doing a live coding exercise.

I was integrating with a currency conversion API and needed to add caching.

The problem was how this would scale with multiple concurrent requests.

A classic cache stampede problem.

I wanted to prevent this with locking.

Locking allows us to control how many threads can access some piece of code.

Note that I rarely worked with low-level code.

But the company I was interviewing for does.

Of course, they'd have this in the interview process.

Here's the situation:

- I knew I needed a locking mechanism
- But the method was async (oof!)
- So I tried to solve this using the `lock` statement

And that's where it all went to shit...

The `lock` statement doesn't work with async-await.

And it makes sense.

You can't guarantee which thread will complete the method.

So what's the solution?

You need to use an asynchronous synchronization primitive.

Luckily, C # has many to choose from.

Semaphore, SemaphoreSlim, Mutex, Monitor, etc.

Two important remarks:

1) Use a timeout when waiting on the semaphore
2) Always release the lock with a try-finally

Here's a tough question for you.

How would you implement a lock in a database?

If you want to find the answer, go here: https://lnkd.in/eVTMfu-y

Would you have nailed this interview?

---

author: Alex Xu
first_line: How to Design Good APIs
hook_150:
How to Design Good APIs

A well-designed API feels invisible, it just works. Behind that simplicity lies a set of consistent design principles that ma
full_text:
How to Design Good APIs

A well-designed API feels invisible, it just works. Behind that simplicity lies a set of consistent design principles that make APIs predictable, secure, and scalable.

Here's what separates good APIs from terrible ones:

- Idempotency: GET, HEAD, PUT, and DELETE should be idempotent. Send the same request twice, get the same result. No unintended side effects. POST and PATCH are not idempotent. Each call creates a new resource or modifies the state differently.

Use idempotency keys stored in Redis or your database. Client sends the same key with retries, server recognizes it and returns the original response instead of processing again.

- Versioning

- Noun-based resource names: Resources should be nouns, not verbs. â€œ/api/productsâ€, not â€œ/api/getProductsâ€.

- Security: Secure every endpoint with proper authentication. Bearer tokens (like JWTs) include a header, payload, and signature to validate requests. Always use HTTPS and verify tokens on every call.

- Pagination: When returning large datasets, use pagination parameters like â€œ?limit=10&offset=20â€ to keep responses efficient and consistent.

Over to you: Whatâ€™s the most common API design mistake youâ€™ve seen, and how would you fix it?

--

author: Gergely Orosz
first_line: One of the best staff-level engineers I worked with is on the market. Their job search is completely
hook_150:
One of the best staff-level engineers I worked with is on the market. Their job search is completely different than almost all job searches:

This is
full_text:
One of the best staff-level engineers I worked with is on the market. Their job search is completely different than almost all job searches:

This is not someone who will fire off a single job application, or reply to any LinkedIn InMail or other message. He already has interviews scheduled with companies where several of his ex-teammates work, and heard that he is looking for his next job. Even if their company is not hiring or doesn't currently need the expertise he brings, they convinced leadership to create space for him.

What you need to know about this person: every team he's ever worked on, he did standout work, in every situation. He got stuff done with high quality, helped others, is not argumentative but is firm in holding up common sense and practicality, and is very curious and humble to top all of this off.

All of his peers liked him on his team. Whenever he worked with another team, engineers and engineering managers on that team got to like him. When we were in org-wide calibration sessions with around 100 people at his level, he was regularly in the "top top" bucket (reserved usually for 5% or less of the population) and did this without playing any time of "political games" or caring about influence. His manager was junior enough of a manager that they didnâ€™t have the influence to "push" to get this kind out outcome: it was several more influential managers, aware of his work, who also concluded that his impact and attitude put him ahead of even their own team members (performance calibrations can be messy and political, I wrote about this at https://lnkd.in/eaavg4h6)

I hate the term "10x engineer" but this engineer is a role model for what a standout engineer is - in fact, some of my writing of standout engineers reference my interactions with folks like him (e.g. my article on the product-minded engineer, this one: https://lnkd.in/et7nWBgW)

And still, from the outside, this engineer is near completely invisible.

He has no social media footprint. His LinkedIn lists his companies he worked at, and nothing else: no technologies, no projects, nothing. His GitHub is empty for the last 5 years, and has perhaps a dozen commits throughout the last 10 (the below is screenshot of his actual GitHub profile).

The only people who know how good he is are those who worked with him (or worked with someone who worked with him.)

He still has to do the same interviews that everyone else does (because no decent company allows even the best hires to bypass the standard process), but thanks to his professional reputation built up inside companies, he is unlikely to have to do the job search that almost everyone has to go through. Well over a decade of standout work can lead here.

(Thank you for all the comments and DMs asking if this person would be interested in job X at location Y - that's the point. No they would not! They already have great options at companies where they know current engineers/leaders from years of working together)

full_text:
One of the most common uses of "vibe coding" I'm hearing from professional devs, outside of prototyping:

Building internal-only tools! Where you don't need to worry about security, scalability, malicious usage.

E.g. data visualization / data viewer tools / one-off data analysis or log analysis tools. LLMs are used a lot for this, based on talking with devs! Especially the newer and more capable versions like Claude Code, OpenAI Codex, Cursor Agent Mode etc.

What would have taken ~2 weeks to put together before for a dev - and so it was never done - is now a few prompts and ~30 minutes! And while the code is throwaway (and code quality is unimportant), the utility is absolutely there!
