full_text:
There's one aspect of engineering that, in my experience, is more challenging than anything else.


ğŸ”® Estimates.

Estimating a project often leads to friction and frustration among teams.

Why?

ğŸ¤ Lack of collaboration: teams frequently work in silos rather than uniting to achieve a common objective.

ğŸ§  Lack of knowledge: there is often no mutual understanding of each otherâ€™s fields.

ğŸŒ Multiple teams involved: more teams involved = more complexity

ğŸ¯ Estimations are essentially guesses: even when some factors are known, they are still largely speculative.

However, while the practice of estimating projects depends on company and team culture, in some cases, estimates are crucial, especially when:

ğŸ¯ The product team needs to decide on priorities
ğŸ‘¥ Multiple parties are involved
â³ The project is time-sensitive

If you want to learn more about how to estimate projects effectively, I'll be sharing an article on the subject with my ~17K subscribers tomorrow.

To provide you with a well-rounded perspective, Iâ€™ve teamed up with my friend Jordan Cutler who will share his extensive experience as a Senior Software Developer and teacher at Maven.

author: ğŸŒ€ Luca Rossi
first_line: What type of manager are you?
hook_150:
What type of manager are you?

Are you:
- An Operator, focused on stability and execution?
- A Guide, nurturing your team culture?
- A Driver, pushing
full_text:
What type of manager are you?

Are you:
- An Operator, focused on stability and execution?
- A Guide, nurturing your team culture?
- A Driver, pushing for change? Or
- A Catalyst, inspiring your team to evolve?

These days I am reviewing the top articles we published this year, and I keep going back to the one about engineering manager archetypes, written with my friend Thiago Ghisi.

Thiago designed two axes along which you can place yourself â€” one about people vs execution, and another about stability vs change. There is so much you can understand about your role (and about yourself) by thinking about what you prioritize in these tradeoffs.

I find these quadrants useful in many ways:
â€“ I can reflect on what I *default* to â€” the style that fits my personality best.
â€“ I can reflect on what my team needs right now. E.g. is it time to nurture culture and tighten screws, or just create momentum and ship fast?
â€“ I can reflect on my team composition. Do we overly skew in some direction? Do we need more (or less) of some of these?

It's a handy mental model that I added to my EM *tools*.

What about you? Do you see yourself in some of these categories?

author: Gergely Orosz
first_line: I didn't believe it until I saw it: but it *really* works in open offices! And you cannot even hear
hook_150:
I didn't believe it until I saw it: but it *really* works in open offices! And you cannot even hear devs "whispering."

This is ML engineer Menoua Kes
full_text:
I didn't believe it until I saw it: but it *really* works in open offices! And you cannot even hear devs "whispering."

This is ML engineer Menoua Keshishian at Wispr Flow HQ, in SF, coding... by whispering to Cursor Agent using his mic (a BOYA Gooseneck that costs ~$70).

I was standing next to him and heard nothing. Everyone in the office does the same.

I have no affiliation with Wispr Flow (this post is not paid, I have no form of financial ties or other etc) - but saw devs like Arvid Kahl use it and swear by it. So I also gave it a go, and it slowly is growing on me for agentic coding (when more context for the agent is more helpful than less). The setup is super clever: you press and hold a usually rarey used button (the fn button on the Mac) and then Wispr "listens" and when you stop, it insers the *meaning* of what you said (not the exact transcript!). When you ramble and self-correct, it gets it right most of the time!

So when I was in SF, I stopped at their offices to say hi to the team and learn more.

CEO and cofounder Tanay Kothari told me that based on their data of 20K users anonymously analyzed, devs who use Wispr do 18% "whispering" (vs 82% typing) in month 1, and 72% "whispering" (vs 28% typing) in month 5, and it grows almost linearly until that point.

It's an interesting new trend, and AI agents are the reason it works.

I shared more details in a summary of my trip to SF, and interesting startups I met: https://lnkd.in/eGZscGXj

Update: in the comments, see notes on how whispering strains vocal cords as much as shouting - keep that in mind! My use case is I am alone in my room and talk with normal voice to the agent, similar to how James Stanier shared below. Perhaps this setup works better for those working remote / in a separate space?

author: Jordan Cutler
first_line: 3 unspoken git tricks that save you TONS of time (no one else shares these):
hook_150:
3 unspoken git tricks that save you TONS of time (no one else shares these):

1. git checkout -

What does it do? It switches you to your previous bra
full_text:
3 unspoken git tricks that save you TONS of time (no one else shares these):

1. git checkout -

What does it do? It switches you to your previous branch. Instead of typing it all out, you can just say "-".

"git checkout jcutler-my-favorite-branch" becomes "git checkout -". I even have an alias set up for git checkout so it becomes "gco -"

AND you can extend this with "git merge -" to merge the last branch you were on, or "cd -" to switch to your previous directory.

2. git bisect

It's the most underrated debugging tool. When something that WAS working starts breaking, run "git bisect start." It will use binary search to figure out the exact commit that broke it in lg(n) tries. 

Because it uses binary search, it can find the bad commit across 1000+ commits in just 10 tries.

3. git checkout HEAD@{1.week.ago}

Or more generally, git checkout branchname@{timeframe}. You can use this to supercharge your git bisect skills. When you use "git bisect", you need to start by finding a "good" and "bad" commit. 

You can easily find the good commit by trying different times of the codebase with this trick.

Any other git tricks like this that don't get enough love?

author: Nicola Ballotta
first_line: Should You Stay Technical as an Engineering Manager? Should You Still Write Code or Be Hands-On?
hook_150:
Should You Stay Technical as an Engineering Manager? Should You Still Write Code or Be Hands-On?


I frequently receive these kinds of questions from
full_text:
Should You Stay Technical as an Engineering Manager? Should You Still Write Code or Be Hands-On?


I frequently receive these kinds of questions from other engineers or first-time EMs who are struggling with similar issues, and I believe the answer is a bit more complex than a simple yes or no like many tend to give.

First of all, a distinction has to be made between "staying technical" and "being hands-on," which are often confused:

ğŸ› ï¸ Staying Technical: involves keeping up with technologies in your environment and understanding their workings.

ğŸ™Œ Being Hands-On: involves directly engaging in technical activities like coding or system development.

While as you progress into leadership roles, we usually observe (with some exceptions) a notable decline in hands-on involvement, the need to stay technical remains constant and becomes crucial for an EM.

So, how do you stay technical?

ğŸ¤ Joining technical meetings to stay up-to-date and engaged with the team.

ğŸ“ Contributing to documentation to solidify understanding and assist the team.

ğŸ› ï¸ Building internal tools to maintain coding skills and create useful resources.

ğŸ¤ Presenting team projects to understand and simplify technical concepts.

These are just a few ways to stay technical.

I wrote about this and much more in my latest newsletter issue, which I'm honored to say was sponsored by CTO Craft Con London (an awesome conference about Technical Leadership).  

Inside the article you'll find a promo code, so you can get an additionalÂ 10% off your conference ticketğŸ‘‡

https://lnkd.in/dv3PYb3g

Since this is still a hot topic, I'd be really interested to hear feedback from other engineers and EMs.


â™»ï¸ PLEASE REPOST IF YOU FOUND IT USEFUL, IT MEANS A LOT TO ME.

author: Gergely Orosz
first_line: Gartner has been out of touch with tech analysis, and their latest report on AI coding assistants sh
hook_150:
Gartner has been out of touch with tech analysis, and their latest report on AI coding assistants shows just how much:

1. They rank Amazon, GitLab, G
full_text:
Gartner has been out of touch with tech analysis, and their latest report on AI coding assistants shows just how much:

1. They rank Amazon, GitLab, GCP, Windsurf all above Cursor. WTF?

In reality: companies I talk to (large and small) are choosing to go with Cursor, after careful evaluation. One example: Cloud Kitchens evaluated both Windsurf and Cursor; ditched Windsurf (and Devin!) and are going with Cursor. They detailed their evaluation: https://lnkd.in/eFnRfEZ6

I've yet to hear a single company choose Amazon Q or Kiro, or Gemni CLI or Juni over Cursor... and don't think that Amazon or "Google Cloud" have any Cursor alternatives (though Gemini CLI is promising, but miles behind Claude Code). Which brings me to my next WTF:

2. No mention of Claude Code or OpenAI Codex. WTF??

Really? For an August 2025 report? Claude Code took the industry by a storm, and OpenAI Codex is also picking up. (Safe to assume neither OpenAI nor Anthropic pay Gartner - a year ago, when Cursor was taking the industry by a storm, Gartner also "forgot" them off the list)

3. Conflict of interests in the report that Gartner does not disclose. WTF?

Cursor pays Gartner nothing to be in the report: but others do! Several companies mentioned in the report much more favorably than Cursor - with a product that is worse! - pay Gartner heavy money to talk to Garnter analysts and rank higher up on this chart. This starts at $50K/year, but the more you pay, the more you can "influence" analysts.

One company that definitely pays Gartner is GitLab: they can offer the report because you HAVE to pay Gartner to even share a report you can brag about. Which is what they do: https://lnkd.in/eXt6q-nd 

(Is it a coincidence that GitLab is also, conveiently ranked above Cursor? Or that Gartner doesn't mention which companies pay them, and which ones don't?)

The cherry on the top: to get access to the Garnter study, it will start at around $50K/year/seat. Yes, really!

Here's a free report on what tools software engineers *actually* use, where no vendors paid to be covered, in The Pragmatic Engineer: https://lnkd.in/eB-ziSYi

Frankly, Gartner is becoming embarrassing. Anyone making decisions based on their reports deserves to choose subpar products, to be fair.

(And for one more example on the analysis quality of The Pragmatic Engineer vs Gartner, check out this analysis from 2023 that went head-on-head with Gartner on cloud development environments, but covered a lot more alternatives, with none of them paying for coverage. I heard it's a lot more detailed than Gartner's $50K report: https://lnkd.in/ekmP49DX )

author: Gergely Orosz
first_line: An anon poster pretended to be an UberEats software engineer, and baited the internet to believe som
hook_150:
An anon poster pretended to be an UberEats software engineer, and baited the internet to believe something completely false:

This Reddit thread claim
full_text:
An anon poster pretended to be an UberEats software engineer, and baited the internet to believe something completely false:

This Reddit thread claiming that a "major food delivery app" is pocketing priority fees and driver benefit fees blew up a few days ago: https://lnkd.in/eFG7M3Vr

It got the attention of journalist Casey Newton (at Platformer.) Casey reached out, and started chatting with this person over Signal. He asked for evidence of the claims, and got a photo of the UberEats badge of this "whistleblower" and a 14-page supposedly internal document uncovering damning things.

Except the badge is absolutely fake and AI-generated, as is the document! I know, because I worked at Uber, still meet with people who work at Uber and the badge has not changed, and looks nothing like the one on the photo. There is no "UberEats" badge; it is not green; the title is obviously not on the badge (if it was, a new badge would need to be issued on every promotion). (I would upload my own badge that I still have - but now I worry that doing so would make it easier for the next troll to create a more realistic badge, and eventually fool a less careful journalist!)

Casey figured out he is being baited and fed AI-generated documents, and confronted this poster: who then simply deleted their Signal account. A lot longer post by Casey with all the details, and the fake 14-page, AI-generated document: https://lnkd.in/euQGqV6e

The problem is how it took this baiter a few minutes to generate plausible sounding lies, but hours for a journalist to figure out it's all fake... and the lie keeps spreading online. As Casey put it so well:

"The rapid spread of the whistleblowerâ€™s post illustrated yetÂ another maximÂ they taught us in J-school:Â A lie can travel halfway around the world before the truth can get its boots on.Â With AI tools at their fingertips, hoaxsters can make those lies travel even faster."

(All other claims were also false, as confirmed by Uber and DoorDash. If there was a whisper of truth in it, you can bet real whistleblowers would come out: there are thousands of people working at each company, and even more ex-employees who would say something if there was an ounce of truth in it...)

At those companies youâ€™ll get questions like â€œwhat is your favorite Python 3.10 feature?â€ and youâ€™ll be told that you have to use only their preferred language in the interview.

author: ğŸŒ€ Luca Rossi
first_line: How do you create an AI coding workflow that actually works? ğŸ¤–
hook_150:
How do you create an AI coding workflow that actually works? ğŸ¤–

In this weekâ€™s podcast episode I had the pleasure of speaking with Birgitta Boeckeler,
full_text:
How do you create an AI coding workflow that actually works? ğŸ¤–

In this weekâ€™s podcast episode I had the pleasure of speaking with Birgitta Boeckeler, distinguished engineer and global lead for AI-assisted software delivery at Thoughtworks.

Birgitta's full-time job is to figure out how engineering teams can make the most out of AI â€” and she shared some fantastic insights about what's working (and what's not) in real-world teams.

Here are a few takeaways from our chat:

â†³ ğŸ”„ ğ—›ğ˜‚ğ—ºğ—®ğ—»-ğ—¶ğ—»-ğ˜ğ—µğ—²-ğ—¹ğ—¼ğ—¼ğ—½ ğ—¶ğ˜€ ğ—¸ğ—²ğ˜† â€” small, incremental changes with constant review beat large autonomous agent workflows. Non-determinism is a feature, not a bug.

â†³ ğŸ“Š ğ—£ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—±ğ˜‚ğ—°ğ˜ğ—¶ğ˜ƒğ—¶ğ˜ğ˜† ğ—´ğ—®ğ—¶ğ—»ğ˜€ ğ˜ƒğ—®ğ—¿ğ˜† ğ˜„ğ—¶ğ—¹ğ—±ğ—¹ğ˜† â€” from negative to 10x improvement, depending on tech stack, codebase quality, and team practices. And remember: if coding is only 30% of your work, you can't exceed 15-20% overall improvement.

â†³ ğŸ§  ğ—•ğ—®ğ—¹ğ—®ğ—»ğ—°ğ—² ğ˜€ğ—¸ğ—²ğ—½ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—°ğ—¶ğ˜€ğ—º ğ˜„ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—µ ğ—®ğ—ºğ—¯ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» â€” the best teams combine critical thinking about AI's limitations with ambitious experimentation. Both perspectives bring value and you should reward them.

â†³ ğŸ—ï¸ ğ—ªğ—µğ—®ğ˜'ğ˜€ ğ—´ğ—¼ğ—¼ğ—± ğ—³ğ—¼ğ—¿ ğ—µğ˜‚ğ—ºğ—®ğ—»ğ˜€ ğ—¶ğ˜€ ğ—´ğ—¼ğ—¼ğ—± ğ—³ğ—¼ğ—¿ ğ—”ğ—œ â€” modular, well-structured code helps AI as much as it helps developers. Clean architecture still matters.

â†³ ğŸ¯ ğ—–ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—®ğ—»ğ˜ ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ˜€ğ—¸ ğ—®ğ˜€ğ˜€ğ—²ğ˜€ğ˜€ğ—ºğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ â€” evaluate probability, impact, and detectability for every AI-generated change. Your experience and "scars from the past" are still crucial.

â†³ ğŸ”§ ğ—§ğ—¼ğ—¼ğ—¹ğ˜€ ğ—®ğ—¿ğ—² ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¿ğ—´ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ â€” whether terminal-based like Claude Code or IDE-based like Cursor, successful tools integrate deeply with existing workflows. 

You can find the links to the episode in the comments!

author: Nicola Ballotta
first_line: Over the past few years as an Engineering Director, there's been a pivotal role that has really help
hook_150:
Over the past few years as an Engineering Director, there's been a pivotal role that has really helped my department succeed.

A Technical Program Man
full_text:
Over the past few years as an Engineering Director, there's been a pivotal role that has really helped my department succeed.

A Technical Program Manager.

The funny thing is that until a couple of years ago, I barely knew what a TPM is ğŸ˜… 

But now, I can't imagine our workflow without one. 

So, what's a TPM?

In simple terms, a Technical Program Manager is an individual responsible for overseeing multiple complex projects, covering everything from planning and execution to delivery.

Why did we need a TPM, and why might you need one too?

 ğŸ“ˆ Increasing project complexity
ğŸ”„ Need for better cross-functional coordination 
ğŸ”— Aligning multidisciplinary teams 
ğŸ› ï¸ Freeing engineers from project management tasks

Here are the benefits we've experienced in the short to medium term after hiring a TPM:

ğŸ¯ Clearer project objectives 
ğŸŒŠ Smoother processes 
ğŸ§­ Strategic project alignment with organizational goals
âš ï¸ Proactive risk management 
ğŸ“Š Resource optimization

Hiring a Technical Program Manager isn't an easy task. 

You often need someone with a "T-Shaped" profile: a generalist with substantial expertise in your specific field and excellent soft skills.

But don't worry, it's Thursday, and I've got all of this and much more covered in The Hybrid Hacker, my newsletter about Engineering, Leadership, and Career Growth, which is sent to 23.3K subscribers.

first_line: One of the biggest regrets in my career was not being aware of engineering career levels early enoug
hook_150:

Learn from my mistake, I don't want the same t
full_text:
One of the biggest regrets in my career was not being aware of engineering career levels early enough.

Learn from my mistake, I don't want the same to happen to you.

Understanding what is expected of each engineering level would have helped me make better decisions earlier in my career.

I put together this mega engineering levels cheatsheet from junior levels up to staff level. 

If you are an engineer, go through it and see if you are due for a promotion, or identify gaps and work towards the next level.

If you are a student, get a sense of what is expected of you as you progress in your career.

Note: These are general guidelines for the standard tech company, using Meta and Google as reference. There can and will be deviations/exceptions depending on company culture and priorities (e.g. some high level engineers still write a lot of code).

author: Alex Xu
first_line: How to Learn AWS?
hook_150:
How to Learn AWS?

AWS is one of the most popular cloud platforms. When AWS goes down, a large part of the Internet goes down.
 
Hereâ€™s a learning map
full_text:
How to Learn AWS?

AWS is one of the most popular cloud platforms. When AWS goes down, a large part of the Internet goes down.
 
Hereâ€™s a learning map that can help you master AWS:

1 - AWS Fundamentals
This includes topics like â€œWhat is AWS?â€, Global Infrastructure, AWS Billing, Management, and IAM basics.
2 - Core Compute, Storage & Networking
This includes compute services like EC2, Lambda, ECS, EKS, Storage Services (such as S3, EBS, EFS, Glacier), and Networking Services (such as VPC, ELB, Route 53).
3 - Databases and Data Services
This includes topics like Relational Databases (RDS MySQL and PostgreSQL), NoSQL, and In-Memory Databases like ElastiCache (Redis and Memcached).
4 - Security, Identity & Compliance
Consists of topics like IAM Deep Dive, Encryption (KMS, S3 SSE), Security Tools, VPC Security Groups, and Compliance-related tools for HIPAA, SOC, and GDPR.
5 - DevOps, Monitoring & Automation
This includes topics like DevOps Tools (CodeCommit, CodeBuild, CodePipeline), Infrastructure as Code, CI/CD Pipelines, Monitoring Tools (CloudWatch, CloudTrail), and Cost Management and Billing Dashboard
6 - Learning Paths and Certifications
Consists of topics like AWS Learning Resources, such as Skill Builder and documentation, and certification paths such as Cloud Practitioner, Solutions Architect Associate, Developer Associate, SysOps, and DevOps Engineer.

Over to you: What else will you add to the list for learning AWS?

--

author: Alex Xu
first_line: Explaining 9 types of API testing.
hook_150:
Explaining 9 types of API testing.Â 
Â 
ğŸ”¹ Smoke TestingÂ 
This is done after API development is complete. Simply validate if the APIs are working and not
full_text:
Explaining 9 types of API testing.Â 
Â 
ğŸ”¹ Smoke TestingÂ 
This is done after API development is complete. Simply validate if the APIs are working and nothing breaks.Â 
Â 
ğŸ”¹ Functional TestingÂ 
This creates a test plan based on the functional requirements and compares the results with the expected results.Â 
Â 
ğŸ”¹ Integration TestingÂ 
This test combines several API calls to perform end-to-end tests. The intra-service communications and data transmissions are tested.Â 
Â 
ğŸ”¹ Regression TestingÂ 
This test ensures that bug fixes or new features shouldnâ€™t break the existing behaviors of APIs.Â 
Â 
ğŸ”¹ Load TestingÂ 
This tests applicationsâ€™ performance by simulating different loads. Then we can calculate the capacity of the application.Â 
Â 
ğŸ”¹ Stress TestingÂ 
We deliberately create high loads to the APIs and test if the APIs are able to function normally.Â 
Â 
ğŸ”¹ Security TestingÂ 
This tests the APIs against all possible external threats.Â 
Â 
ğŸ”¹ UI TestingÂ 
This tests the UI interactions with the APIs to make sure the data can be displayed properly.Â 
Â 
ğŸ”¹ Fuzz TestingÂ 
This injects invalid or unexpected input data into the API and tries to crash the API. In this way, it identifies the API vulnerabilities.

first_line: The AI Agent Tech Stack
hook_150:
The AI Agent Tech Stack

1. Foundation Models: Large-scale pre-trained language models that serve as the â€œbrainsâ€ of AI agents, enabling capabilities
full_text:
The AI Agent Tech Stack

1. Foundation Models: Large-scale pre-trained language models that serve as the â€œbrainsâ€ of AI agents, enabling capabilities like reasoning, text generation, coding, and question answering.
2. Data Storage: This layer handles vector databases and memory storage systems used by AI agents to store and retrieve context, embeddings, or documents.
3. Agent Development Frameworks: These frameworks help developers build, orchestrate, and manage multi-step AI agents and their workflows.
4. Observability: This category enables monitoring, debugging, and logging of AI agent behavior and performance in real-time.
5. Tool Execution: These platforms allow AI agents to interface with real-world tools (for example, APIs, browsers, external systems) to complete complex tasks.
6. Memory Management: These systems manage long-term and short-term memory for agents, helping them retain useful context and learn from past interactions.

Over to you: What else will you add to the list?

--

author: Alex Xu
first_line: Things Every Developer Should Know: Concurrency is ğğğ“ parallelism.
hook_150:
Things Every Developer Should Know: Concurrency is ğğğ“ parallelism.
.
.
In system design, it is important to understand the difference between concurr
full_text:
Things Every Developer Should Know: Concurrency is ğğğ“ parallelism.
.
.
In system design, it is important to understand the difference between concurrency and parallelism. 

As Rob Pyke(one of the creators of GoLang) stated:â€œ Concurrency is about ğğğšğ¥ğ¢ğ§ğ  ğ°ğ¢ğ­ğ¡ lots of things at once. Parallelism is about ğğ¨ğ¢ğ§ğ  lots of things at once." This distinction emphasizes that concurrency is more about the ğğğ¬ğ¢ğ ğ§ of a program, while parallelism is about the ğğ±ğğœğ®ğ­ğ¢ğ¨ğ§. 

Concurrency is about dealing with multiple things at once. It involves structuring a program to handle multiple tasks simultaneously, where the tasks can start, run, and complete in overlapping time periods, but not necessarily at the same instant. 

Concurrency is about the composition of independently executing processes and describes a program's ability to manage multiple tasks by making progress on them without necessarily completing one before it starts another.

Parallelism, on the other hand, refers to the simultaneous execution of multiple computations. It is the technique of running two or more tasks or computations at the same time, utilizing multiple processors or cores within a computer to perform several operations concurrently. Parallelism requires hardware with multiple processing units, and its primary goal is to increase the throughput and computational speed of a system.

In practical terms, concurrency enables a program to remain responsive to input, perform background tasks, and handle multiple operations in a seemingly simultaneous manner, even on a single-core processor. It's particularly useful in I/O-bound and high-latency operations where programs need to wait for external events, such as file, network, or user interactions.

Parallelism, with its ability to perform multiple operations at the same time, is crucial in CPU-bound tasks where computational speed and throughput are the bottlenecks. Applications that require heavy mathematical computations, data analysis, image processing, and real-time processing can significantly benefit from parallel execution.

--

author: Ethan Evans
first_line: I know an engineer who has been stuck in a mid-level role for 30+ years because he doesnâ€™t care what
hook_150: I know an engineer who has been stuck in a mid-level role for 30+ years because he doesnâ€™t care what his managers think. He cares about technical exce
full_text:
I know an engineer who has been stuck in a mid-level role for 30+ years because he doesnâ€™t care what his managers think. He cares about technical excellence. That is great, but it wonâ€™t get you promoted. 

Technical excellence alone does not get engineers promoted because technical excellence alone does not create business value.  To get promoted, especially at higher levels, an engineer needs to make it clear that they have an impact in at least one of these three things: 

1) Revenue Generation

This could mean they launch new features/products, facilitate payments, build systems to handle more customers, or a number of other things. However, the connection between the engineerâ€™s work and the revenue or opportunity for revenue should be clear. 

2) Cost Reduction

On the other side of revenue is cost reduction. A businessâ€™s profits increase when its costs decrease, so doing any work that improves the efficiency of the business will be seen as valuable. 

3) Moat Construction

If an engineerâ€™s work doesnâ€™t have direct impact on profit but does help create a competitive advantage for the company, this will also be seen as incredibly valuable. 

The ways in which an engineer can influence each of these three things is practically unlimited, but the important thing for engineers to understand is that doing value-adding work will lead to promotion. Doing maintenance work (exclusively) leads to a maintenance position. 

This may be a very stable job, which is great if that is what you want. But it wonâ€™t be a fast-growing or far-reaching career. If you want one of those, you have to create growth for the company. 

I wrote an article for Jordan Cutlerâ€™s â€œHigh Growth Engineerâ€ newsletter that goes through how you can become an engineer that drives impact and gets promoted to higher and higher roles. 

The insights come from my 25+ years as an engineering leader throughout my career, based directly on what has led me to promote scores of engineers. 

It includes the list of the 5 top traits in engineers that I promoted, as well as stories and examples of engineers creating outsized value. 

Read the article here: https://lnkd.in/eh-CdNW9

Engineers and leaders- How can engineers create business value and get rewarded for it?

first_line: Big Data Pipeline Cheatsheet for AWS, Azure, and Google Cloud
hook_150:
Big Data Pipeline Cheatsheet for AWS, Azure, and Google Cloud

Each platform offers a comprehensive suite of services that cover the entire lifecycle:
full_text:
Big Data Pipeline Cheatsheet for AWS, Azure, and Google Cloud

Each platform offers a comprehensive suite of services that cover the entire lifecycle:

1 - Ingestion: Collecting data from various sources
2 - Data Lake: Storing raw data
3 - Computation: Processing and analyzing data
4 - Data Warehouse: Storing structured data
5 - Presentation: Visualizing and reporting insights

AWS uses services like Kinesis for data streaming, S3 for storage, EMR for processing, RedShift for warehousing, and QuickSight for visualization.

Azureâ€™s pipeline includes Event Hubs for ingestion, Data Lake Store for storage, Databricks for processing, Cosmos DB for warehousing, and Power BI for presentation.

GCP offers PubSub for data streaming, Cloud Storage for data lakes, DataProc and DataFlow for processing, BigQuery for warehousing, and Data Studio for visualization.

Over to you: What else would you add to the pipeline?

author: Jordan Cutler
first_line: This one communication shift took my friend from rejections to landing a senior 270k offer in big te
hook_150:
This one communication shift took my friend from rejections to landing a senior 270k offer in big tech.

âŒ Before, he'd get a question like, "Tell me
full_text:
This one communication shift took my friend from rejections to landing a senior 270k offer in big tech.

âŒ Before, he'd get a question like, "Tell me about how you made an impact on your team."

And he'd answer like, "Yeah, there was this one time... < speak for a minute on the story >... oh and there was this other time too... < another one >." 

But the interviewer would already be lost by the end of the first one. They want someone senior, someone who can take a step back first.

I told him, you need to show your STRUCTURED thought process. Seniors speak in bullet points first, then details after.

âœ… So he switched it to, "Sure. When I'm making impact on the team, I like to think about 3 things--opportunity, effort, and risk. Each quarter, we map projects on these axes and one of the projects I proposed had high opportunity and medium effort/risk. Let me tell you more about that one, why I worked on it, and how I drove it forward..."

Once he switched to this, his interviewer's eyes started lighting up early on in his answer. He finally figured it out. Then, the offers followed.

So why is the second one better?
1. It shows you don't just jump into solutions.
2. It shows your decision criteria for action. You won't work on unimpactful work.
3. It gives your interviewer an overview first, almost like an "agenda" at the start of a presentation. They know what to expect.

Before you answer, take a step back, share your thought process, and show your structured thinking. Don't just dive in and start going off on stories.

--
Recently when working with Torsten Walbaum (ex-Rippling/Uber/Meta Director), I learned there was a framework this relates to called MECE--mutually exclusive, collectively exhaustive. When it gets applied, it looks a lot like the example my friend used to get his senior offers.

In today's High Growth Engineer post, Torsten shows you how to use it for 5 use cases as an engineer--interviews, investigations, debugging, explaining a system, and when proposing ideas.

Join 80k+ engineers and check it out here: https://lnkd.in/e-MBdkjg

hook_150:

full_text:
An interesting things about software engineers is that in a single career one could work in 4, 5, or more different domains.

In my career alone I build software for supply chain logistics, finance, eCommerce, Marketing & AdTech, Pharmacy, etc.

In a single career a wide awake software engineer could learn how business works, how the economy works, bring lessons from one domain to help them in another.

Very few other fields have access to this much cross-domain expertise. Access to experts to teach them the domain.

But some software engineers throw this advantage away by simply not caring at all about the business they are building for.

Donâ€™t be one of those engineers. 

Build up that asset stack of cross-domain knowledge, over a long career itâ€™ll be more helpful to you than you can imagine.

author: Gergely Orosz
first_line: A worrying trend: AI startups in the US are pushing extreme working hours, similar to the "996" work
hook_150: A worrying trend: AI startups in the US are pushing extreme working hours, similar to the "996" work structure in China. This doesn't feel that it wil
full_text:
A worrying trend: AI startups in the US are pushing extreme working hours, similar to the "996" work structure in China. This doesn't feel that it will lead to anything good - but the mix of the promise of riches and a sense of urgency about "AGI" and more startups doing it is making this work setup more popular.

If it was my first-ever job and I had no family and did not care for the health impact of poor sleep and overwork: sure, I'd do it. Today I see that this would be silly: the more I work without breaks, the worse my work gets.

Food for thought that some of the startups that advocate for the most work are seeing pretty disappointing outcomes, like AI ad maker Icon (that opted for 7 days a week work week, just to see themselves pivoting to becoming an ads agency).

More of my thoughts in today's The Pragmatic Engineer issue on this: https://lnkd.in/e7xnZeAP

author: Gergely Orosz
first_line: This is very unusual/weird: average tenure at Big Tech is dramatically increasing since 2023. But wh
hook_150:
This is very unusual/weird: average tenure at Big Tech is dramatically increasing since 2023. But why?

Two possible explanations:

1. Big Tech softwa
full_text:
This is very unusual/weird: average tenure at Big Tech is dramatically increasing since 2023. But why?

Two possible explanations:

1. Big Tech software engineers might be less likely to change jobs than before. Perhaps because of the poor job market, or perhaps because it's harder to get comparable job offers.

2. A hiring slowdown across all of Big Tech. From a commenter on The Pragmatic Engineer:

"Previously, big tech average tenure hovered around 1.5-3 years, not because people were churning jobs that frequently, but because tech companies were hiring at an exponentially growing rate (+20-25% year over year) for so many years in a row. In such an environment, the vast majority of employees are actually new hires, and even when there is zero attrition, the average tenure would still be a very low 2-3 years."

This is one of several interesting findings about the tech jobs market in 2025, from today's The Pragmatic Engineer deepdive. Read the full issue here: https://lnkd.in/eye2TA6T

full_text:
Talked with the Claude Code team on how they build Claude Code.Â Interesting things I've not seen elsewhere:

- 90% of the code in Claude Code was written by Claude Code, and closer 100% of tests

- Some pretty important features were vibe coded with Claude Code... like the rendering engine that translates Markdown to the UI (Claude returns Markdown!)

- Engineers, on average, merge 5 pull requests per day (this is high!!)

- The last year, the engineering team's size doubled at Anthropic. The PR throughput (PRs per engineer, per day) instead of going down or staying the same... went up by 67%! This was the same time when every dev inside Anthropic started to use Claude Code

- Mockups feel like a thing of the past when you can build 5-10 working prototypes per day. And this is what the team is doing - we go into a specific example with ~20 prototypes over 2 days.

The deepdive in today's The Pragmatic Engineer is here: https://lnkd.in/eBvzDmRK 

Thanks a lot to founding Claude Code engineers Boris Cherny and Sid Bidasaria, and founding PM Catherine Wu for talking with me!

Here's whatÂ Sulman ChoudhryÂ (Head of
full_text:
I recently learned that OpenAI has started to hire junior software engineers... and it's working GREAT for them:

Here's whatÂ Sulman ChoudhryÂ (Head of ChatGPT Engineering) told me: he and the team have been very pleasantly surprised by how the junior engineers they hire are basically "super junior" engineers, who end up teaching the rest of the team ways to use AI tools in new ways, oftentimes more efficiently (and are very fast learners - probably partially because of using AI as well!)

Below is an amusing story that highlights how this new generation thinks a lot more "AI-native" in how they solve problems... to the point that it surprises even experienced engineers.

The companies that have stopped hiring juniors could well be missing out on exactly this type of energy spreading!

Read more in this week's The Pragmatic Engineer deepdive here: https://lnkd.in/eGZscGXj

Update: my point with all this is not about OpenAI: it's that the whole "companies should not hire juniors because of X or Y" (which has been a recurring theme since 2020 to today) just probably don't make that much sense when you look at the bigger picture? A balanced team almost always works better. Companies like OpenAI can afford to only hire senior people (and did it for a long time!) and are learning the same. Same with eg Netflix (who are now hiring new grads!), Shopify (hiring 1,000 interns per year) etc

author: Milan JovanoviÄ‡
first_line: Not all Load Balancing strategies are created equal.
hook_150:
Not all Load Balancing strategies are created equal.

If you are using YARP (Yet Another Reverse Proxy) in .NET, you have 5 built-in ways to distribut
full_text:
Not all Load Balancing strategies are created equal.

If you are using YARP (Yet Another Reverse Proxy) in .NET, you have 5 built-in ways to distribute traffic. But which one should you choose?

Here is the breakdown:

1. RoundRobin: The classic. It cycles through servers evenly. Simple, but it assumes all servers are equally fast.

2. LeastRequests: The smart choice. It sends traffic to the server currently doing the least work.

3. Random: It picks a server at random. Surprisingly effective for high-volume, uniform workloads.

4. PowerOfTwoChoices: The balanced approach. It picks two random servers and chooses the one with fewer requests. It avoids the overhead of checking every server.

5. FirstAlphabetical: The "sticky" one. It always picks the first available server. Good for failover setups, bad for load distribution.

Most people stick with RoundRobin, but switching to LeastRequests can significantly improve tail latency in systems where request times vary.

I dive deeper into how to scale horizontally using YARP here: https://lnkd.in/daDNMpmB

Which strategy is your default choice?

---

author: Alex Xu
first_line: Top 20 System Design Concepts You Should Know
hook_150:
Top 20 System Design Concepts You Should Know

1. Load Balancing: Distributes traffic across multiple servers for reliability and availability.
2. Cac
full_text:
Top 20 System Design Concepts You Should Know

1. Load Balancing: Distributes traffic across multiple servers for reliability and availability.
2. Caching: Stores frequently accessed data in memory for faster access.
3. Database Sharding: Splits databases to handle large-scale data growth.
4. Replication: Copies data across replicas for availability and fault tolerance.
5. CAP Theorem: Trade-off between consistency, availability, and partition tolerance.
6. Consistent Hashing: Distributes load evenly in dynamic server environments.
7. Message Queues: Decouples services using asynchronous event-driven architecture.
8. Rate Limiting: Controls request frequency to prevent system overload.
9. API Gateway: Centralized entry point for routing API requests.
10. Microservices: Breaks systems into independent, loosely coupled services.
11. Service Discovery: Locates services dynamically in distributed systems.
12. CDN: Delivers content from edge servers for speed.
13. Database Indexing: Speeds up queries by indexing important fields.
14. Data Partitioning: Divides data across nodes for scalability and performance.
15. Eventual Consistency: Guarantees consistency over time in distributed databases
16. WebSockets: Enables bi-directional communication for live updates.
17. Scalability: Increases capacity by upgrading or adding machines.
18. Fault Tolerance: Ensures system availability during hardware/software failures.
19. Monitoring: Tracks metrics and logs to understand system health.
20. Authentication & Authorization: Controls user access and verifies identity securely.

Over to you: Which other System Design concept will you add to the list?

--

author: Milan JovanoviÄ‡
first_line: The riskiest line of code you'll write today is the one without a feature flag.
hook_150:
The riskiest line of code you'll write today is the one without a feature flag.

Fortunately, .NET has you covered right out of the box.

Feature flag
full_text:
The riskiest line of code you'll write today is the one without a feature flag.

Fortunately, .NET has you covered right out of the box.

Feature flags are a software development technique that allows you to wrap application features in a conditional statement.

You can then toggle the feature on or off at runtime to control which features are enabled.

.NET already has feature flag support built in.

You can use the IFeatureManager in your code to check whether a feature is enabled.

Want to learn more about using feature flags?

Check out this article: https://lnkd.in/ddxmMg4V

There are many popular services for managing feature flags.

I've used LaunchDarkly often, and recently also PostHog (it offers many more features).

full_text:

- Management (Team Lead or Engineering Manager)
- IC (Tech Lead or Staff Engineer)
- Architecture (Software Architect)

I consider these to be starting engineering leadership roles, where people in such roles are expected to be multipliers for others and not primarily contributing by finishing assigned tasks.

And these are the skills you need to develop:
- System Design
- Leadership
- Management (for management path)
- Technical details
- Product/Business
- Communication/Influence

The level of depth you need to go in each depends on which path you take.

To help you with this.

Here are 200+ resources to get better at any skills mentioned above: https://lnkd.in/eRMgZ9Ee

author: Alex Xu
first_line: How to Debug a Slow API?
hook_150:
How to Debug a Slow API?

Your API is slow. Users are complaining. And you have no idea where to start looking. Here is the systematic approach to tra
full_text:
How to Debug a Slow API?

Your API is slow. Users are complaining. And you have no idea where to start looking. Here is the systematic approach to track down what is killing your API.

Start with the network: High latency? Throw a CDN in front of your static assets. Large payloads? Compress your responses. These are quick wins that don't require touching code.

Check your backend code next: This is where most slowdowns hide. CPU-heavy operations should run in the background. Complicated business logic that needs simplification. Blocking synchronous calls that should be async. Profile it, find the hot paths, fix them.

Check the database: Missing indexes are the classic culprit. Also watch for N+1 queries, where you are hammering the database hundreds of times when one batch query would do.

Don't forget external APIs: That Stripe call, that Google Maps request, they are outside your control. Make parallel calls where you can. Set aggressive timeouts and retries so one slow third-party doesn't tank your whole response.

Finally, check your infrastructure: Maxed-out servers need auto-scaling. Connection pool limits need tuning. Sometimes the problem isn't your code at all, itâ€™s that you are trying to serve 10,000 requests with resources built for 100.

The key is being methodical. Don't just throw solutions at the wall. Measure first, identify the actual bottleneck, then fix it.

Over to you: What is the weirdest performance issue you have tracked down?

author: Milan JovanoviÄ‡
first_line: How did we make a simple idea so complicated?
hook_150:
How did we make a simple idea so complicated?

CQRS is the simplest pattern out there.

First, there was CQS: Command Query Separation.

What does thi
full_text:
How did we make a simple idea so complicated?

CQRS is the simplest pattern out there.

First, there was CQS: Command Query Separation.

What does this mean? We split an object's methods into write (command) and read (query) methods.

CQRS is the evolution of CQS. CQRS works on the architectural level. At the same time, CQS works on the method (or class) level.

The CQRS pattern uses separate models for reading and updating data.

This separation can be logical OR physical.

My preferred approach is starting with logical CQRS.

One database + separate flows for writes and reads.

You can design a data model fine-tuned for each operation.

A lot of developers stay away from CQRS because they think it's complex.

The reality is you're probably already applying CQRS principles without knowing it.

Here's a simple implementation: https://lnkd.in/d-qUdpn3

What do you think about the CQRS pattern?

---

author: Milan JovanoviÄ‡
first_line: What is the cleanest way to get configuration values in .NET?
hook_150:
What is the cleanest way to get configuration values in .NET?

I use the Options pattern.

Here's why you should know about it.

App configuration liv
full_text:
What is the cleanest way to get configuration values in .NET?

I use the Options pattern.

Here's why you should know about it.

App configuration lives in:

- Environment variables
- (appsettings) JSON files
- User secrets
- Other config providers

You can get individual values using the IConfiguration interface.

But this is error-prone and won't scale, so I don't recommend it.

Instead, I use the Options pattern:

- Create a class to represent the settings
- Bind the class properties to application settings (JSON)
- Consume the Options pattern in my code using IOption

You can also add data annotations to your settings class for simple validation.

Here's how you can implement the Options pattern in .NET: https://lnkd.in/gjVBDHqM

Do you know the difference between IOptions, IOptionsSnapshot and IOptionsMonitor?

author: Jordan Cutler
first_line: This framework I never knew I needed got me compliments on my communication within a week.
hook_150:
This framework I never knew I needed got me compliments on my communication within a week.

It's called MECE.

Huh? mice? No. MECE ğŸ˜‚. It stands for "M
full_text:
This framework I never knew I needed got me compliments on my communication within a week.

It's called MECE.

Huh? mice? No. MECE ğŸ˜‚. It stands for "Mutually Exclusive, Collectively Exhaustive." It forces your communication to be structured.

Let's take an incident investigation as an example. Many times, engineers are dropping messages in the channel like throwing darts.

âŒ Before: "It could be the landing page. No, that's not it. Maybe seasonality? Nope, that's not it either... anyone have other ideas?"

âœ… After: "If signups are down, it's either actually down or it's a false positive. If it's a false positive, we can check for seasonality or a data issue. If it's an actual drop, it could be that it's iOS only, android only, or both. Let's narrow it down."

MECE tells you to come up with all the mutually exclusive and many options as possible upfront, then narrow down and cross out. 

This has a few benefits:
1. You can literally SEE the structure via a tree this gives your communication and thinking
2. Once you see it, you can delegate each of those to others working on the issue
3. Finally, you can cross out each item on the tree as you go, and give accurate estimates to leaders of when it'll be resolved. No more, "we're not sure when it'll be fixed. It's too ambiguous." 

To apply it yourself, before your next message, think about how you can communicate using a "tree structure" like the one on the right. Avoid windy roads and darts.

Have you heard of MECE before and where else do you think you can use it?

--
Tomorrow, I'll share 4 more use cases you can use this to level up your communication, thinking, and problem-solving. We have a special guest post from Torsten Walbaum (ex-Rippling, Uber, Google) on High Growth Engineer.

author: Gergely Orosz
first_line: The story of how "AI" made me use an LLM in addition to my existing SaaS subscription (Grammarly) be
hook_150: The story of how "AI" made me use an LLM in addition to my existing SaaS subscription (Grammarly) because of how this SaaS failed at the core task I p
full_text:
The story of how "AI" made me use an LLM in addition to my existing SaaS subscription (Grammarly) because of how this SaaS failed at the core task I pay for:

As context, recently more typos made it into The Pragmatic Engineer: sorry about this! I was confused how this keeps happening, because we do 2 rounds of manual edits with my editor, and then a final spellcheck with Grammarly. And yet, typos in company names or product names kept getting through!

Well, turns out that Grammarly does not flag typos in e.g. "ChatGTP" (see the typo?) or company names.

If we would be talking about a 1990s spell checker, I could make this pass, because these are words that are not in a dictionary. But Grammarly claims to be AI-powered!

Curiously, all other LLMs (Claude, Gemini etc) all find the spelling errors that Grammarly cannot spot.

And this is the story of how we changed our final spell check from Grammarly (that doesn't do its job, when this is its only job!) to a general-purpose LLM that does it (when this is not even its job, it's just good at it).

I was a paying customer for Grammarly for 5+ years, and this was disappointing. The final check with a tool to filter out typos left in the text will now happen with Claude or Gemini.

"AI" is not replacing SaaS businesses: but SaaS businesses that do not keep up with capabilities general LLMs already could well lose customers.

Update: thanks to Grammarly CEO Shishir Mehrotra for his response below, in the first comment.

author: Milan JovanoviÄ‡
first_line: I love working with the Service Discovery library in .NET.
hook_150:
I love working with the Service Discovery library in .NET.

It's a lightweight configuration-based approach.

This actually came out of the effort don
full_text:
I love working with the Service Discovery library in .NET.

It's a lightweight configuration-based approach.

This actually came out of the effort done in Aspire.

If you're new to this concept, here's a quick breakdown.

Service discovery allows developers to reference external services using logical names instead of physical IP addresses and ports.

There's a centralized store for services to register themselves.

Clients can query the service registry to find the service's physical address.

The service discovery library for .NET is simpler, though.

It still lets you use logical names to refer to external services.

However, the discovery side is "lacking".

You have to specify the physical addresses in the application settings.

Here's a step-by-step tutorial: https://lnkd.in/eX4Wy3jD

You can configure the service URLs during deployment in your CI/CD pipelines.

Or even use a central configuration store (Azure App Configuration) for service discovery URLs.

---

author: Alex Xu
first_line: 5 REST API Authentication Methods
hook_150:
5 REST API Authentication Methods

1. Basic Authentication: Clients include a Base64-encoded username and password in every request header, which is s
full_text:
5 REST API Authentication Methods

1. Basic Authentication: Clients include a Base64-encoded username and password in every request header, which is simple but insecure since credentials are transmitted in plaintext. Useful in quick prototypes or internal services over secure networks.
2. Session Authentication: After login, the server creates a session record and issues a cookie. Subsequent requests send that cookie so the server can validate user state. Used in traditional web-apps.
3. Token Authentication: Clients authenticate once to receive a signed token, then present the token on each request for stateless authentication. Used in single-page applications and modern APIs that require scalable, stateless authentication.
4. OAuth-Based Authentication: Clients obtain an access token via an authorization grant from an OAuth provider, then use that token to call resource servers on the userâ€™s behalf. Used in cases of third-party integrations or apps that need delegated access to user data.
5. API Key Authentication: Clients present a predefined key (often in headers or query strings) with each request. The server verifies the key to authorize access. Used in service-to-service or machine-to-machine APIs where simple credential checks are sufficient.

Over to you: Which other API Authentication method have you seen?

--

I tested out all the popular approaches...

SqlBulkCopy is your winner. It's the fastest way to insert a large amount of data into SQL Server. But it does require writing more code than the other approaches.

Postgres has the COPY command, which works similarly.

Here are 5 more solutions I compared: https://lnkd.in/eearSh_z

Which one would you use?

author: Alex Xu
first_line: How LLMs See the World
hook_150:
How LLMs See the World

When you type "Hello world" into ChatGPT or Claude, the model isn't processing those letters and spaces like you're reading th
full_text:
How LLMs See the World

When you type "Hello world" into ChatGPT or Claude, the model isn't processing those letters and spaces like you're reading this post right now. It's converting everything into numbers through a process most people never think about.

Preprocessing comes first. Text gets normalized. Unicode characters, spacing quirks, and special symbols, they all get cleaned up and standardized. "Hello world" becomes a consistent format that the model can actually work with.

Then comes tokenization. This is where things get interesting. The model splits text into tokens, and there are different approaches.

1 - Character-based tokenization breaks everything down to individual characters. "Hello world" becomes ["H", "e", "l", "l", "o", " ", "w", "o", "r", "l", "d"]. Simple but inefficient.

2 - Word-based splits on whole words. ["Hello", "world"]. Cleaner but struggles with rare words and creates massive vocabularies.

3 - Subword-based is what modern LLMs actually use. GPT, Gemini, Claude, they all rely on this. "Hello world" becomes something like ["Hell", "o", "world"]. It balances efficiency with flexibility, handling rare words by breaking them into known subword pieces.

The final step is Token IDs. Those subwords get mapped to numbers like [15496, 345, 995]. Each token ID corresponds to an embedding vector inside the model. That's what the neural network actually processes.

Over to you: Why do some models handle code better than natural language? Is it the tokenizer?

--

Back to Rome after some great time in Berlin at the CTO Craft Con!

I had the privilege to keynote the first day ğŸ™ and I brought some thoughts about h
full_text:
Back to Rome after some great time in Berlin at the CTO Craft Con!

I had the privilege to keynote the first day ğŸ™ and I brought some thoughts about how software engineering teams should think about AI.

The truth is everything these days feels shaky and early, so I believe good mental models are more useful than specific practices. And my favorite one is: ğ˜„ğ—µğ—®ğ˜â€™ğ˜€ ğ—´ğ—¼ğ—¼ğ—± ğ—³ğ—¼ğ—¿ ğ—µğ˜‚ğ—ºğ—®ğ—»ğ˜€ ğ—¶ğ˜€ ğ—´ğ—¼ğ—¼ğ—± ğ—³ğ—¼ğ—¿ ğ—”ğ—œ.

Whatâ€™s evident from the countless conversations and data points we have been collecting over the past few months, is that if you have good engineering practices in place, AI is going to amplify them. 

AI thrives on the same things humans thrive on: good docs, clear abstractions, good testing, small batches. It also makes it *easier* to implement them, by lifting a lot of grunt work off of our shoulders.

So the ROI of good engineering is just skyrocketing: good practices are now easier to put in place + more valuable, because they benefit both human and AI productivity.

The opposite is also true: if your house is a mess, AI is just going to create more mess.

So, all in all, thereâ€™s never been a better time to be a software engineer â€” letâ€™s get to work!

p.s. it was great to meet with so many friends at the conference! Shout-outs to Hannah (finally in person!), Joel, Melinda, Patrick, Danilo and many more I am sure I am forgetting!

author: Milan JovanoviÄ‡
first_line: In .NET, you usually have to choose between Speed and Consistency.
hook_150:
In .NET, you usually have to choose between Speed and Consistency.

In-Memory Caching (IMemoryCache):
âœ… Blazing fast (nanoseconds).
âŒ Data is stuck on
full_text:
In .NET, you usually have to choose between Speed and Consistency.

In-Memory Caching (IMemoryCache):
âœ… Blazing fast (nanoseconds).
âŒ Data is stuck on one server. If you have 10 nodes, you have 10 caches.

Distributed Caching (IDistributedCache / Redis):
âœ… Shared across all servers. Consistent data.
âŒ Network latency. Serialization costs. It's slower.

The Solution: HybridCache.

Don't choose one. Use both.

A Hybrid Cache creates a tiered architecture:

- L1 (Local): The app checks RAM first. If it's there, return instantly.
- L2 (Distributed): If missing locally, check Redis.
- Source: If missing in Redis, fetch from DB, then populate both L1 and L2.

While Microsoft is working on a native implementation, I still swear by FusionCache as the most robust, battle-tested library for this.

I wrote a guide on how to set this up properly: https://lnkd.in/d6NKgMVp

Are you currently using just Redis, or a multi-layer cache?

---

author: Alex Xu
first_line: How DNS Works
hook_150:
How DNS Works

You type a domain name and hit enter, but what actually happens before that webpage loads is more complex than most people realize. DNS
full_text:
How DNS Works

You type a domain name and hit enter, but what actually happens before that webpage loads is more complex than most people realize. DNS is the phonebook of the internet, and every request you make triggers a chain of lookups across multiple servers. 

Step 1: Someone types bytebytego. com into their browser and presses enter. 

Step 2: Before doing anything, the browser looks for a cached IP address. Operating system cache gets checked too. 

Step 3: Cache miss triggers a DNS query. The browser sends a query to the configured DNS resolver, usually provided by your ISP or a service like Google DNS or Cloudflare.

Step 4: Resolver checks its own cache. 

Step 5-6: If the resolver doesn't have the answer cached, it asks the root servers, â€œWhere can I find .com?â€ For bytebytego. com, the root server responds with the address of the .com TLD name server. 

Step 7-8: Resolver queries the .com TLD server. TLD server returns the authoritative server address. 

Step 9-10: This server has the actual A/AAAA record mapping the domain to an IP address. The resolver finally gets the answer: 172. 67. 21. 11 for bytebytego. com.

Step 11-12: The IP gets cached at the resolver level for future lookups, and returned to the browser.

Step 13-14: The browser stores this for its own future use, and uses the IP to make the actual HTTP request. 

Step 15: The web server returns the requested content.

All this happens in milliseconds, before your first page even starts loading.

Over to you: Which DNS tools or commands do you rely on most, dig, nslookup, or something else?

--

author: ğŸŒ€ Luca Rossi
first_line: Today I published an article about something very close to my heart: note-taking. It's a review of "
hook_150: Today I published an article about something very close to my heart: note-taking. It's a review of "How to Take Smart Notes" â€” a book that completely
full_text:
Today I published an article about something very close to my heart: note-taking. It's a review of "How to Take Smart Notes" â€” a book that completely changed how I work and think ğŸ‘‡

This book introduced me to the ğ—­ğ—²ğ˜ğ˜ğ—²ğ—¹ğ—¸ğ—®ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—²ğ—» method used by Niklas Luhmann, who published 70+ books and 400+ scientific papers in 30 years (!!). His secret? A system of 90,000 interconnected notes that acted as his second brain.

But here's the thing: after 5 years and 600+ notes of my own, I've learned that you don't need to copy Luhmann exactly. In fact, I donâ€™t. You need something sustainable that works for you.

Here are some things I learned:

â†³ âœï¸ ğ—ªğ—¿ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—¶ğ˜€ ğ˜ğ—µğ—¶ğ—»ğ—¸ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ â€” you don't write to capture thoughts: you write to create them. Writing forces linear thinking and reveals both meaning and inconsistencies.

â†³ ğŸ± ğ—•ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—®ğ—¸ ğ—±ğ—¼ğ˜„ğ—» ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ˜„ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—¸ â€” separate capture (save everything raw), organize (periodic review), and express (create output). Trying to do all at once == writer's block.

â†³ ğŸ“¥ ğ—–ğ—®ğ—½ğ˜ğ˜‚ğ—¿ğ—² ğ—²ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜†ğ˜ğ—µğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´, ğ—¸ğ—²ğ—²ğ—½ ğ—µğ—®ğ—¹ğ—³ ğ—¼ğ—³ ğ—¶ğ˜ â€” during my weekly review, I delete most of what I captured in the prior days. And that's fine!

â†³ ğŸª£ ğ—£ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—·ğ—²ğ—°ğ˜ğ˜€, ğ—¥ğ—²ğ˜€ğ—½ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ—¯ğ—¶ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—²ğ˜€, ğ—®ğ—»ğ—± ğ—§ğ—¼ğ—½ğ—¶ğ—°ğ˜€ â€” I organize notes by actionability. Projects have deadlines, responsibilities recur, while topics are just areas of interests.

â†³ ğŸ¤– ğ—”ğ—œ ğ—µğ—²ğ—¹ğ—½ğ˜€ ğ—°ğ—®ğ—½ğ˜ğ˜‚ğ—¿ğ—², ğ—»ğ—¼ğ˜ ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—´ğ—®ğ—»ğ—¶ğ˜‡ğ—² â€” I have found that AI is great for capturing and summarizing content, but organizing is where I need make the connections. We canâ€™t outsource your thinking. Same thing with writing.

So, after 260+ articles and 600+ notes, I confirm: good note-taking compounds â€” but it's a journey. 

As in software, it's not about creating a perfect system: it's about a workflow that grows with you, which you keep iterating on.

Full article in the comments! ğŸ‘‡

author: Rahul Pandey
first_line: One of my early career mistakes was believing that 'expertise' is difficult or impossible to attain.
hook_150:
One of my early career mistakes was believing that 'expertise' is difficult or impossible to attain.

A Staff Engineer at Pinterest exposed my mistake
full_text:
One of my early career mistakes was believing that 'expertise' is difficult or impossible to attain.

A Staff Engineer at Pinterest exposed my mistake: within 2 weeks, he knew more about the codebase than me, even though I had been working in that area for a year.

Not only did he ramp up dramatically faster, he was able to understand the abstractions far better than me. 

After a few more weeks, he understood several abstractions and libraries more deeply than anyone in the entire company.

Expertise is not something you magically get when you become senior enough. It's a prerequisite for seniority, and you can start building expertise today.

You can become more knowledgeable than anyoneÂ as long as you narrow the scope appropriately. e.g. "In one afternoon, I can understand more about the flags to configureÂ git logÂ compared to anyone on my team of 10 people."

Jordan Cutler talks more about this in his guide about becoming the go-to expert as a software engineer: https://lnkd.in/gBvqibJ2

full_text:
How does Shopify execute at startup speed â€” but with 4,000 engineers? âš¡ï¸

Today I published a deep dive with Eytan Seidman, Director of Product for the Developer Platform at Shopify, about how they achieve startup velocity at enterprise scale.

One of their secrets is a unique approach that combines continuous delivery with strategic storytelling through biannual "Editions."

Here are a few things that I learned:

â†³ ğŸ­ ğ—˜ğ—±ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜€ ğ—®ğ—¿ğ—² ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ˜†ğ˜ğ—²ğ—¹ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´, ğ—»ğ—¼ğ˜ ğ˜„ğ—®ğ˜ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—³ğ—®ğ—¹ğ—¹ â€” teams ship continuously, but twice a year they bundle major updates into cohesive narratives that capture market attention.

â†³ ğŸ”¬ ğ—–ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¿ğ—´ğ—²ğ—»ğ—°ğ—² ğ—°ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—®ğ˜ğ—²ğ˜€ ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—µğ—²ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—»ğ—°ğ—² â€” before each Edition, teams stop building new features and focus entirely on integration, stress-testing the full user journey to avoid "feature soup."

â†³ ğŸ‘¥ ğ—›ğ˜†ğ—¯ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ—± ğ˜ğ—²ğ—®ğ—º ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—¿ğ˜‚ğ—°ğ˜ğ˜‚ğ—¿ğ—² â€” durable teams own complex domains for deep expertise, while task forces tackle new initiatives for agility. Best of both worlds.

â†³ ğŸ›ï¸ ğ—˜ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜†ğ˜ğ—µğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—®ğ˜€ ğ—–ğ—¼ğ—±ğ—² â€” they adopted a declarative, code-first approach to their platform, which is paying huge dividents with AI. Now AI can read and update config files and run full apps without touching GUIs.

â†³ ğŸ’» ğ—œğ——ğ—˜ ğ—®ğ˜€ ğ—›ğ˜‚ğ—¯ â€” meeting developers where they are increasingly means never making them leave their development environment. The platform comes to them, not the other way around.

Link to the full article in the comments! ğŸ‘‡

author: Nicola Ballotta
first_line: I'm not a genius, nor do I have a high IQ, but one thing has been key to my success.
hook_150:
I'm not a genius, nor do I have a high IQ, but one thing has been key to my success.


Observation.

As an introvert, I enjoy observing and listening
full_text:
I'm not a genius, nor do I have a high IQ, but one thing has been key to my success.


Observation.

As an introvert, I enjoy observing and listening to other people, and this is what has brought me to where I am today and continues to keep me learning.

This is how:

ğŸ› ï¸ I became an Engineer:
â®‘ When I was younger, I observed many other engineers. How they approached problems, how they built resilient systems, how they coded.

ğŸ‘¥ I became an Engineering Manager:
â®‘ At one point in my career, I found myself in the EM position without any previous experience. I started following other EMs or just managers, read about their experiences, and asked them to share their learnings.

ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’¼ I became a Director:
â®‘ As with the EM role, there were no courses to learn how to play in this position. That's why I approached other people in these roles, observed the ones in my company, and learned from them.

âœï¸ I recently became a newsletter author:
â®‘ I'm not bad at writing; in fact, I love it. But writing for a wider audience and in a language that isn't your first, that's something else. That's why before launching my newsletter, I approached other writers, listened to their experiences, and took a lot of inspiration from all of them.

Books are a good way to learn. 

Doing things yourself and learning from mistakes is a great way to learn. 

ğŸ’¡ Observing, listening, and imitating other people is, in my opinion, still the best and fastest way to learn something.

How do you learn?


â™»ï¸ PLEASE REPOST IF YOU FOUND IT USEFUL, IT MEANS A LOT TO ME.

author: Nicola Ballotta
first_line: There's one mistake I've made multiple times in my career that has led to losing great talents.
hook_150:
There's one mistake I've made multiple times in my career that has led to losing great talents.


âŒ Not caring for people from the beginning.

You spe
full_text:
There's one mistake I've made multiple times in my career that has led to losing great talents.


âŒ Not caring for people from the beginning.

You spend an incredible amount of effort to hire someone:

- kicking off the hiring process
- assessing hundreds of profiles
- doing tons of interviews
- checking a lot of code challenges

Then, you find a talent that perfectly fits your team. You get them onboarded, and since everything seems to be going well, you forget about them.

Eventually, perhaps after a year or two, you start to notice signs of disengagement from this team member. You sense their unhappiness, until the day they ask for a meeting to announce their resignation.

And so you ask if there's something you can do to change their mind, offering a salary raise or more benefits.

But guess what? It's too late.

I've learned that the hard way. 

As soon as you onboard a new team member, that's when you have to start caring about them and ensuring:

ğŸ¤ Regular check-ins (1:1s): focus on how they're feeling, not just updates on what they've accomplished.

ğŸ’° Proactive salary reviews: if your team members are performing well, they deserve recognition through raises. And while the budget isn't always under your control, it's your duty to advocate for them.

ğŸŒ± Comprehensive support: offer mentorship and development opportunities to help them grow. Make them feel valued not just for their work but for their potential.

âš–ï¸ Work-life balance: encourage a healthy balance. Overworking can lead to burnout, which no raise can compensate for.

author: Alex Xu
first_line: Latency vs. Throughput
hook_150:
Latency vs. Throughput

Ever wondered why your app feels slow even when the bandwidth looks fine? Latency and throughput explain two very different st
full_text:
Latency vs. Throughput

Ever wondered why your app feels slow even when the bandwidth looks fine? Latency and throughput explain two very different stories of performance.

Latency measures the delay per packet. It is what users feel when they click a button. Itâ€™s responsiveness. It is the time for one request to travel from the server to the end device. This includes server processing time, queuing delays, propagation through the network, transmission delays, and the last-mile connection to the user's device. 

Throughput measures volume per second. It is how much data successfully gets delivered in a given timeframe. Not how fast each packet moves, but how many packets flow through the pipe. Throughput is capacity. High throughput means the system handles the load without choking.

Over to you: How do you measure these metrics in a way that actually predicts when things will break?

--

first_line: Bad code is bad only if you need to change it. If it looks bad, but is stable, it doesnâ€™t pose any c
hook_150:
Bad code is bad only if you need to change it. If it looks bad, but is stable, it doesnâ€™t pose any concerns.

This might seem trivial, but it has deep
full_text:
Bad code is bad only if you need to change it. If it looks bad, but is stable, it doesnâ€™t pose any concerns.

This might seem trivial, but it has deep implications. The main one is that you should focus your quality work on ğ—µğ—¼ğ˜ğ˜€ğ—½ğ—¼ğ˜ğ˜€ (cit. Adam Tornhill): the parts of your codebase that are frequently subject to change.

As humans we are bad at judging this intuitively, so a lot of work on tech debt is simply misguided: it either happens on badâ€”but stableâ€”code, or on areas that are active but already in relatively good shape.

This is also hard to evaluate because activity distribution is extremely skewed: in most codebases, ~5% of the code gets 90% of the activity.

This reminds me of something from my startup days.

During an M&A conversation, the buyerâ€™s consulting firm ran a technical due diligence. They found several areas of poor quality codeâ€”as we expected. In fact, over time we had doubled down on specific parts of the product we cared about, while phasing out others. The latter stayed experimental: less testing, more duplication, etc.

What I didnâ€™t expect was how hard this proved to be to argue. We pointed to the strategic parts we were proud of, but they weighted the sketchy marginal code as an equal part of the whole.

In other words, the ğ—³ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—¾ğ˜‚ğ—²ğ—»ğ—°ğ˜† ğ—¼ğ—³ ğ—°ğ—µğ—®ğ—»ğ—´ğ—² wasnâ€™t considered.

Eventually the M&A failed for a variety of reasons. This was not explicitly mentioned as a blocker, but I always suspected it contributed.

I had a chat with Adam a few months ago that influenced a lot of how I think about this topic. I wrote an article from it, which I am linking in the comments ğŸ‘‡

author: ğŸŒ€ Luca Rossi
first_line: What does *minimum viable testing* look like?
hook_150:
What does *minimum viable testing* look like?

Testing is one of the topics on which I receive the most questions from the newsletter. But these are u
full_text:
What does *minimum viable testing* look like?

Testing is one of the topics on which I receive the most questions from the newsletter. But these are usually not like: â€œhow do I test things thoroughly?" But rather â€œhow do I get the best bang for my buck?â€

So as always YMMV, but here is my quick cheat sheet:

ğŸ­) ğ—¨ğ˜€ğ—² ğ—® ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—° ğ˜ğ˜†ğ—½ğ—²ğ—± ğ—¹ğ—®ğ—»ğ—´ğ˜‚ğ—®ğ—´ğ—²

Most languages today have statically typed versions you can adopt, e.g. Typescript for Javascript, or Sorbet for Ruby.

My opinion is that this is a no-brainer for 99% of teams.

Static types catch a ton of bugs early, make AI safer, and self-document the code.

ğŸ®) ğ—ªğ—¿ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—² ğ˜‚ğ—»ğ—¶ğ˜ ğ˜ğ—²ğ˜€ğ˜ğ˜€ *ğ˜„ğ—µğ—²ğ—» ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—¹ğ—²ğ˜ƒğ—®ğ—»ğ˜*

Unit tests are an important part of your testing investment. However, I am not adamant about their coverage â€” you should write them for whatever is non-trivial or subject to implementation changes in the future.

ğŸ¯) ğ—ªğ—¿ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—² ğ—½ğ—¹ğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ğ˜† ğ—¼ğ—³ ğ—¶ğ—»ğ˜ğ—²ğ—´ğ—¿ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» ğ˜ğ—²ğ˜€ğ˜ğ˜€

Integration tests are about testing execution paths that involve multiple functions / components. Figure out the most important ones for each area of your product, and test them in depth. 

To identify them, you can think about business paths based on how your product is used. API endpoints are also usually good candidates.

Sometimes, the difference between unit and integration is a bit murky, but it doesnâ€™t matter. Just focus on what feels worthwhile to be tested.

ğŸ°) ğ—ªğ—¿ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—² ğ—® ğ—³ğ—²ğ˜„, ğ—°ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—°ğ—®ğ—¹ ğ—²ğ—»ğ—±-ğ˜ğ—¼-ğ—²ğ—»ğ—± ğ˜ğ—²ğ˜€ğ˜ğ˜€

E2E tests are expensive to develop and maintain. My rule of thumb is to invest in testing those parts that you would check manually anyway. The entire goal of E2E is to remove manual checks, so you can release faster.

If you are an e-commerce, you may start by testing the main purchase funnel, checkout included. If you are a SaaS, you may test that new customers are able to subscribe, and the core features used by your existing ones.

ğŸ±) ğ—”ğ˜ƒğ—¼ğ—¶ğ—± ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—®ğ—´ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—¶ğ—³ ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ ğ—°ğ—®ğ—»

I wrote a full article about this, but the TL;DR is you can probably avoid a staging environment by implementing some combination of canary rollouts and live PR previews. I also have a friend who also does video walkthroughs for PR, and they look great.

The idea is: the fewer steps to production, the faster you release, the better feedback loop you have, which also helps stability because you recover faster from mistakes.

author: Milan JovanoviÄ‡
first_line: The worst kind of bug is the one that explodes 3 days after deployment.
hook_150:
The worst kind of bug is the one that explodes 3 days after deployment.

This is the hidden danger of the standard Options Pattern in .NET.

You might
full_text:
The worst kind of bug is the one that explodes 3 days after deployment.

This is the hidden danger of the standard Options Pattern in .NET.

You might bind your appsettings.json to a class, inject it, and everything looks fine. The app starts up perfectly.

But if a required API Key is missing? You won't know until a user triggers that specific feature, and the app crashes.

This is why "Fail Fast" is crucial for configuration.

If your config is invalid, your application should refuse to start. Period.

You can achieve this by extending the Options Pattern with IValidateOptions.

Instead of just binding data, you attach validation logic:

1. Define rules (e.g., "ApiKey cannot be null", "RetryCount must be > 0").
2. Register the validator.
3. If the config breaks the rules, the DI container throws an exception immediately at startup.

I took this a step further and integrated FluentValidation to make the rules cleaner and more expressive.

Here is the complete implementation code: https://lnkd.in/djz5Yfux

author: Alex Xu
first_line: Top Developer Tools You Can Use in 2026
hook_150:
Top Developer Tools You Can Use in 2026

1 - Code Editors & IDEs: These tools help developers write, edit, and debug code with greater efficiency. Exa
full_text:
Top Developer Tools You Can Use in 2026

1 - Code Editors & IDEs: These tools help developers write, edit, and debug code with greater efficiency. Examples are Visual Code, IntelliJ IDEA, PyCharm, Cursor, Eclipse, etc.
2 - Version Control Systems: Track code changes over time and enable collaboration between team members. Examples are Git, GitHub, Gitlab, Bitbucket, AWS Code Commit, etc.
3 - Testing Tools: Help ensure that code behaves as expected by identifying bugs before they reach production. Examples are JUnit, Selenium, Playwright, Cypress, etc.
4 - CI/CD Tools: They help automate the process of building and deploying code to speed up delivery. Examples are Jenkins, GitHub Actions, Circle CI, Travis CI, and Code Pipeline.
5 - Containerization and Orchestration: Helps package applications and their dependencies into containers to make sure they run across environments in a consistent manner. Examples are Docker, Kubernetes, Podman, Containerd, Rancher, etc.
6 - Project Management Tools: Helps the development teams plan, organize, and track the development of tasks. Examples are JIRA, Asana, Trello, ClickUp, Notion, etc.
7 - API Testing Tools: They help test and validate APIs to ensure stable communication between services and with external consumers. Examples are Postman, Swagger, Hopscotch, Insomnia, etc.
8 - AI-Powered Developer Tools: They are mainly used to boost developer productivity with code suggestions, error detection, and automated code generation. Examples are ChatGPT, Claude Code, Cursor, Copilot, Qodo, etc.

Over to you: Which other tools have you used?

full_text:
Best Resources to Learn AI in 2026

The AI resources can be divided into different types such as:

1 - Foundational and Modern AI Books
Books like AI Engineering, Machine Learning System Design Interview, Generative AI System Design Interview, and Designing Machine Learning Systems cover both principles and practical system patterns.

2 - Research and Engineering Blogs
Follow OpenAI Research, Anthropic Engineering, DeepMind Blog, and AI2 to stay current with new architectures and applied research.

3 - Courses and YouTube Channels
Courses like Stanford CS229 and CS230 build solid ML foundations. YouTube channels such as Two Minute Papers and ByteByteAI offer concise, visual learning on cutting-edge topics.

4 - AI Newsletters
Subscribe to The Batch (Deeplearning. ai), ByteByteGo, Rundown AI, and Ahead of AI to learn about major AI updates, model releases, and research highlights.

5 - Influential Research Papers
Key papers include Attention Is All You Need, Scaling Laws for Neural Language Models, InstructGPT, BERT, and DDPM. Each represents a major shift in how modern AI systems are built and trained.
