full_text:
I recently interviewed at a few different places. At the end of each interview, the interviewer usually asks: â€œdo you have any questions for me?â€

Donâ€™t waste this opportunity with questions that donâ€™t matter, or that you can ask your recruiter.

Here are some questions I like to help me understand team health & company culture:

- How much vacation have you taken this year?
- What is the process when an incident happens on production? While youâ€™re asleep?
- How do you know what to work on next?
- If you learn something really cool, how do you share that with the other engineers?
- What is something youâ€™d change about the company?
- What would cause you to leave the company?
- How messy is engineering? Do you feel empowered to fix the mess?
- Do you deploy code on Fridays?
- What is the managerâ€™s leadership style?
- Are you working on a promotion? How do you stay on track?
- What are some fun facts about your teammates?

You likely wonâ€™t have time for every one of these, so pick and choose what feels right in the moment, and what you need most to know.

Best of luck in your interviews! â¤ï¸

The photo is from Kinokuniya Shinjuku, the flagship bookstore complex in
full_text:
Pinch me: my book is this week's best-seller in Japan's largest book store:

The photo is from Kinokuniya Shinjuku, the flagship bookstore complex in the Shinjuku district of Tokyo. It is probably the most famous and historic book retailer in Japan. It's a multi-floor shop with a massive selection, known for its wide range of specialized books. You can see two copies of The Software Engineer's Guidebook on the top shelf on the picture.

The Japanese version of The Software Engineer's Guidebook launched two weeks ago, translated by Ryuichi Kubuki (thank you for the phenomenal work!) published by O'Reilly Japan. Oâ€™Reilly told me that the book was temporarily out of stock for a few days, thanks to stronger-than-expected demand.

I love how the book's cover is very different from the English version - though if you zoom in you can see "The Software Engineer's Guidebook" in English showing up on the left side of the book.

If you live in Japan, you can order the book on Amazon Japan and find it in book stores: https://lnkd.in/e7FE2EXB

And also on the best seller list - and on the bottom right part of the photo - isÂ  the Japanese version of the excellent AI Engineering book byÂ Chip Huyen! Chip's book is a masterpiece, I recommend it to anyone and everyone who would like to get up to speed on building on top of LLMs.

author: Nicola Ballotta
first_line: A couple of weeks ago, I made a decision that dramatically changed the start of my 2024.
hook_150:
A couple of weeks ago, I made a decision that dramatically changed the start of my 2024.


ğŸ–ï¸ It was nothing too fancy. I simply chose to take a two-w
full_text:
A couple of weeks ago, I made a decision that dramatically changed the start of my 2024.


ğŸ–ï¸ It was nothing too fancy. I simply chose to take a two-week break, completely disconnected from everything.

I admit, I was a bit afraid about stepping away from LinkedIn, my newsletter, my job, and everything else. The fear of losing touch with my audience was real, but I had to weigh that against burnout, something I'm all too familiar with.

 So, I took the 'risk' and disconnected for two weeks.

Guess what?

ğŸ‰ Nothing bad happened and the best part is that I came back much more relaxed, with tons of fresh ideas for 2024.

Sometimes we're so engaged in what we love doing, that it becomes challenging to step back and take a break. But here's a reminder: it's better to 'lose' two weeks to rest than to face burnout and potentially lose months, or even a year.

ğŸ’¡ To help manage my work-life balance, I've developed a personal framework that I call the '3-3-3 Anti-Burnout Rule'. 

This means dedicating: 

- at least 3 hours each week
- 3 days each month,
- 3 weeks each year 

to completely disconnect, rest, reflect, and self-assess. While I strive for more, I never go below these thresholds.

ğŸš€ This not only keeps me away from burnout, but it also helps sharpen and skyrocket my productivity.

And you? Are you taking any regular fully disconnected time?


â™»ï¸ PLEASE REPOST IF YOU FOUND IT USEFUL, IT MEANS A LOT TO ME.

first_line: There's one thing that could easily disrupt your team without you even noticing.
hook_150:
There's one thing that could easily disrupt your team without you even noticing.


Accepting bad behavior.

Being tolerant with your people, accepting
full_text:
There's one thing that could easily disrupt your team without you even noticing.


Accepting bad behavior.

Being tolerant with your people, accepting them making mistakes is perfectly fine; but there are several unwritten rules and behaviors that should generally never be accepted because they can undermine teamwork, trust, and productivity.

Some of them include:

ğŸš« Disrespect: any form of disrespect towards team members.
ğŸ™…â€â™‚ï¸ Bullying or Harassment: making fun of or bothering others.
ğŸ§¨ Undermining Others: deliberately sabotaging or undermining a colleague's work.
âŒ Ignoring Decisions: once a decision is made by the team, ignoring or actively working against it.
ğŸ™ˆ Not Acknowledging Mistakes: failing to take responsibility for errors.
ğŸ† Taking Credit for Others' Work: claiming others' achievements as one's own.
ğŸ’¸ Misusing Resources: using team resources for personal gain.
ğŸ¤ Breaking Confidentiality: sharing sensitive information without authorization.

  
In the past, it happened to me to accept some of these behaviors. I did that in good faith, with all the best intentions and to avoid losing some key people.

But that was a huge mistake.

Protecting one person can sometimes put the whole team at risk.

What are other bad behaviors you should not accept in a team?

author: Alex Xu
first_line: Top 5 common ways to improve API performance.
hook_150:
Top 5 common ways to improve API performance.

Result Pagination:Â 
This method is used to optimize large result sets by streaming them back to the cli
full_text:
Top 5 common ways to improve API performance.

Result Pagination:Â 
This method is used to optimize large result sets by streaming them back to the client, enhancing service responsiveness and user experience.

Asynchronous Logging:Â 
This approach involves sending logs to a lock-free buffer and returning immediately, rather than dealing with the disk on every call. Logs are periodically flushed to the disk, significantly reducing I/O overhead.

Data Caching:Â 
Frequently accessed data can be stored in a cache to speed up retrieval. Clients check the cache before querying the database, with data storage solutions like Redis offering faster access due to in-memory storage.

Payload Compression:Â 
To reduce data transmission time, requests and responses can be compressed (e.g., using gzip), making the upload and download processes quicker.

Connection Pooling:Â 
This technique involves using a pool of open connections to manage database interaction, which reduces the overhead associated with opening and closing connections each time data needs to be loaded. The pool manages the lifecycle of connections for efficient resource use.

Over to you: What other ways do you use to improve API performance?

--

SQL statements are executed by the database system in several steps, including:

full_text:
Visualizing a SQL query

SQL statements are executed by the database system in several steps, including:
- Parsing the SQL statement and checking its validity
- Transforming the SQL into an internal representation, such as relational algebra
- Optimizing the internal representation and creating an execution plan that utilizes index information
- Executing the plan and returning the results

first_line: At the beginning of my career as an Engineering Leader, there was one thing that I struggled with.
hook_150:

ğŸ˜– My impatience.

As an individual contributor,
full_text:
At the beginning of my career as an Engineering Leader, there was one thing that I struggled with. 


ğŸ˜– My impatience.

As an individual contributor, you receive a task, complete it, and feel rewarded.

However, as an Engineering Leader, immediate results are rare.

You must work diligently to achieve larger projects, guide your team toward your vision, and influence others.

â³ This process takes time. Depending on the goal, it could take weeks, months, or even years.

For this reason, it's quite easy to focus on daily failures instead of concentrating on the bigger picture, which is often better than what you believed.

It's a mental exercise that takes time to get used to.

Here's what helped me:

ğŸ“ Journaling: being able to reflect on past experiences helps maintain perspective on the bigger picture.

â™»ï¸ Establishing routines: sometimes, the Engineering Leader role feels intangible in terms of daily work. Establishing routines contributes to making progress more visible.

ğŸ“š Viewing failures as learning opportunities: don't be discouraged by failures, as they provide valuable lessons for both you and your team.

ğŸŒŸ Celebrating successes: acknowledge and celebrate achievements, both big and small, within your team. This helps reinforce the idea of progress.

What strategies do you use to overcome impatience?

author: Milan JovanoviÄ‡
first_line: I failed a .NET interview question that looked easy.
hook_150:
I failed a .NET interview question that looked easy.

â€œAdd caching to an async API.â€

The tricky part isnâ€™t caching.
Itâ€™s what happens when 50 request
full_text:
I failed a .NET interview question that looked easy.

â€œAdd caching to an async API.â€

The tricky part isnâ€™t caching.
Itâ€™s what happens when 50 requests hit the same cold cache at once:
- race conditions
- cache stampedes (thundering herd)
- why ConcurrentDictionary still isnâ€™t enough
- why you canâ€™t await inside a lock
- the SemaphoreSlim async-lock pattern (with try/finally, double-check, timeout)
- scaling it with per-key locks to reduce contention

I break it down step-by-step using a currency conversion example, and show the exact refactor path from â€œworks locallyâ€ to â€œworks under load.â€

Watch it here: https://lnkd.in/dyN7_acX

author: Gregor Ojstersek
first_line: 6 different strategies to become a CTO.
hook_150:
6 different strategies to become a CTO.

1. Start a company
This is the route of a lot of uncertainty and continuous learning on the job. But the retu
full_text:
6 different strategies to become a CTO.

1. Start a company
This is the route of a lot of uncertainty and continuous learning on the job. But the returns on this may be immense.

2. Become a founding engineer
This is especially for someoneÂ who isÂ good at building MVPs.

3. Go through the Management path
The more you grow in the management path, the more you become a good fit for mid+ size companies as a CTO.

4. Go through the Architecture path
This might be a good path for you if you like to still stay in technical details and you love to design great systems. But keep in mind that as a CTO of mid+ size companies, you wonâ€™t be doing that anymore.

5. Go through the IC path
You are a good fit for small-size companies, but you will need to learn the management skills for mid+ size companies.

6. Become a CTO through other roles, mostly Product
Iâ€™ve seen where CTOs come from roles such as DevOps (Head of DevOps), QA (Head of QA), etc. but Iâ€™ve also seen where a CPO or Head of Product transitioned to either a CTPO (Chief Technology and Product Officer) or pure CTO role.

Learn about every strategy in detail here: https://lnkd.in/eFJvcsCi

More w
full_text:
You work hard for a month, two months, half a year, an entire year. You promise yourself you'll take a pause to recharge.

But then you don't.

More work to come, new projects, new prospects. More, more, more. Until recharging becomes impossible.

ğŸ”¥ Welcome to burnout.

This silent beast is bad for your personal life and your work. It drains your energy, creativity, enthusiasm, and joy.

Been there, done that. 

How to avoid it? 

ğŸ’¡ Switch Your Mindset: more doesn't mean better. Working more doesn't lead to promotions; working smarter does.

ğŸš§ Set Boundaries: define your work hours and stick to them. Make it clear to your colleagues and yourself when you're 'off the clock'.

ğŸ›‘ Take Regular Breaks: short, frequent breaks throughout the day can help you maintain consistent productivity and prevent mental fatigue.

ğŸ™… Learn to Say No: you can't do everything. Taking on too much is the surest way to burn out.

ğŸ”‹ Prioritize Your Energy Sources: Family? Friends? Sports? Whatever gives you energy and joy, make it a priority.

â™»ï¸ PLEASE REPOST IF YOU FOUND IT USEFUL, IT MEANS A LOT TO ME.

author: Milan JovanoviÄ‡
first_line: Looking for a simple message bus in .NET?
hook_150:
Looking for a simple message bus in .NET?

I recommend taking a look at System Threading Channels.

You can implement a simple in-memory message bus u
full_text:
Looking for a simple message bus in .NET?

I recommend taking a look at System Threading Channels.

You can implement a simple in-memory message bus using Channels in .NET.

Channels implement the producer-consumer pattern:

- Producers asynchronously produce data
- Consumers asynchronously consume that data

A channel has a Writer and Reader, that you can use to publish and consume messages. respectively.

Here's how you can use this to implement a simple message bus: https://lnkd.in/ekfJZd5n

Remember that this is still an in-memory bus, so it's not reliable.

You can implement resiliency around this, but it only goes so far.

author: Alex Xu
first_line: API Vs SDK!
hook_150:
API Vs SDK!Â 
Â 
API (Application Programming Interface) and SDK (Software Development Kit) are essential tools in the software development world, but t
full_text:
API Vs SDK!Â 
Â 
API (Application Programming Interface) and SDK (Software Development Kit) are essential tools in the software development world, but they serve distinct purposes:Â 
Â 
API:Â 
An API is a set of rules and protocols that allows different software applications and services to communicate with each other.Â 
Â 
1. It defines how software components should interact.Â 
2. Facilitates data exchange and functionality access between software components.Â 
3. Typically consists of endpoints, requests, and responses.Â 
Â 
SDK:Â 
An SDK is a comprehensive package of tools, libraries, sample code, and documentation that assists developers in building applications for a particular platform, framework, or hardware.Â 
Â 
1. Offers higher-level abstractions, simplifying development for a specific platform.Â 
2. Tailored to specific platforms or frameworks, ensuring compatibility and optimal performance on that platform.Â 
3. Offer access to advanced features and capabilities specific to the platform, which might be otherwise challenging to implement from scratch.Â 
Â 
The choice between APIs and SDKs depends on the development goals and requirements of the project.Â 
Â 
Over to you:Â 
Which do you find yourself gravitating towards â€“ APIs or SDKs â€“ Every implementation has a unique story to tell. What's yours? 

--

One of the most popular and widely used options is UML.

C4 stands for:

hook_150:
If you need to run a task "Every Friday at 5 PM," how do you implement it?

A While(true) loop with a Thread.Sleep() is not the answer.

You need a ro
full_text:
If you need to run a task "Every Friday at 5 PM," how do you implement it?

A While(true) loop with a Thread.Sleep() is not the answer.

You need a robust scheduler that understands Cron Expressions.

A Cron expression allows you to define complex recurring schedules with a compact string.

For example:

â€¢ 15 10 * * * = 10:15 AM every day.
â€¢ 15 10 * * MON-FRI = 10:15 AM, but only on weekdays.

In the .NET ecosystem, the heavyweight champion for this is Quartz.

It parses these expressions for you and ensures your background services fire exactly when they are supposed to.

I broke down how to configure your first job and trigger in this article: https://lnkd.in/dfy-U7jp

What library do you currently use for background jobs?

author: Milan JovanoviÄ‡
first_line: Clean code tip:
hook_150:
Clean code tip:

- Merge nested IF statements into one condition

I often make this simple change to improve code readability.

Clean code principles
full_text:
Clean code tip:

- Merge nested IF statements into one condition

I often make this simple change to improve code readability.

Clean code principles will make you a better developer.

But what is clean code in the first place?

Clean code is code that's:

- Easy to read
- Easy to maintain
- Easy to understand

Writing clean code is a skill.

It's a skill you can learn and improve with practice.

In the initial example:

- Nesting increases complexity
- Nesting makes the code harder to reason about

The solution is to combine the nested IF statements into a single IF.

Three ways you can do this:

- Write an inline boolean expression
- Expose a method with the expression
- Create a variable with the expression

But this is just the start.

Here are 8 more clean code tips: https://lnkd.in/dt84mr9J

Which solution do you like better?

---

first_line: As managers, we always say we should cut meetings whose value is low, that is, lower than the opport
hook_150:
As managers, we always say we should cut meetings whose value is low, that is, lower than the opportunity cost of attendees' time.

In my experience,
full_text:
As managers, we always say we should cut meetings whose value is low, that is, lower than the opportunity cost of attendees' time.

In my experience, though, this is tricky to judge. The ROI of ceremonies is often not linear, e.g:

â†³ Daily standups may feel like a waste of time until you casually intercept a big blocker.
â†³ Retrospectives may seem shallow until a project goes bad and it prompts a real discussion.

Some processes are simply designed to run *at a loss* most of the time, and then have a few instances that repay the whole bill.

I feel that, as humans, we are bad at assessing these situations. When the value distribution is uneven, we need longer feedback loops â€” and we donâ€™t like that.

This is one of the cruxes of moving from IC to management. As an engineer, most feedback loops are extremely short: you write code, it works, deploy to prod, check how it goes. As a manager, good luck with that! When it comes to how your team worksâ€”as a systemâ€”you need many cycles to figure out how things are doing. And a full cycle goes from minutes/hours (coding) to weeks (management).

I wish a good week to all the managers out there! â¤ï¸

As a manager, good luck with that! When it comes to how your team worksâ€”as a systemâ€”you need many cycles to figure out how things are doing. author: Gregor Ojstersek
first_line: Make sure to try to avoid the New Leader Syndrome as an engineer.
hook_150:
Make sure to try to avoid the New Leader Syndrome as an engineer.

What I like to call a â€œNew Leader Syndromeâ€ is when you feel that you need to showc
full_text:
Make sure to try to avoid the New Leader Syndrome as an engineer.

What I like to call a â€œNew Leader Syndromeâ€ is when you feel that you need to showcase an extraordinary amount of effort or competence to justify that you deserve to lead that project or team.

And for every individual, it shows up differently:

1. Working extra hours and staying a long time in the office to â€œshowâ€ everyone how great and committed you are

2. Trying to be the best at everything, while also leading the team

3. Always being available and quickly responding to every question

4. Itâ€™s also common for more experienced leaders as well, and it shows when they feel pressured to make quick, visible changes to prove their value

So, this is my advice: When you first step into leadership, itâ€™s common to feel the need to prove yourself by doing more. Extra effort at the beginning is normal, but if you make it unsustainable, thatâ€™s not.

Leadership is not about being perfect or doing everything yourself. Itâ€™s about solving the right problems, setting clear expectations, and enabling others to succeed.

To learn more, read the latest Engineering Leadership article: https://lnkd.in/erHjEY25

author: Jordan Cutler
first_line: Here's a simple trick to avoid your proposals getting rejected: Don't make it a "yes" or "no" decisi
hook_150:
Here's a simple trick to avoid your proposals getting rejected: Don't make it a "yes" or "no" decision. 

Make it a "which one" decision. And make you
full_text:
Here's a simple trick to avoid your proposals getting rejected: Don't make it a "yes" or "no" decision. 

Make it a "which one" decision. And make your recommendation the obvious choice.

When you say "Can I do <x>?" it's a "yes" or "no" decision. Most of the time, especially when your request might be to another team, the easiest thing is for them to say no. That keeps the status quo which feels safe.

When you provide options, it makes the best choice for the business clear and easy to pick.

Here's a before and after example.

âŒ Before: Can you add rate limiting to the search endpoint? Our frontend is sending too many requests.

âœ… After:
Hi team, we're seeing high request volumes on the search endpoint. We have a few options to address this:
1. Backend rate limiting (recommended). All clients will be supported out of the box.
2. Add client side throttling. However, all clients will need to be updated
3. If we do nothing, we'll keep hitting our max load and failing requests

What are your thoughts?

This is a simplified example, but the "after" did a few things:
â€¢ It reduces cognitive load by calling out ways we can solve it up front
â€¢ It makes it really weird to choose option 3. It's clear that (1) or (2) will be better than doing nothing. 
â€¢ It makes it really easy to pick option 1. It's already been laid out as recommended and shows why it's the best choice.

Combined, it leads to you getting the outcome you want.

--
Tomorrow, I'll release an article with 5 tips like this on overcoming friction and getting past "no." To not miss it, join 77k+ engineers and check the link next to my picture above.

author: Milan JovanoviÄ‡
first_line: Most people think Redis is just used for caching.
hook_150:
Most people think Redis is just used for caching.

But you can also use it as a vector database.

Here are a few use cases for Redis:

- Counters
- Ra
full_text:
Most people think Redis is just used for caching.

But you can also use it as a vector database.

Here are a few use cases for Redis:

- Counters
- Rate limiting
- Leaderboards
- Session store
- Message queue
- Distributed locking

And of course, Redis as a vector database.

What are vectors?

Vectors are sequences of numbers that represent data.

You use an LLM to generate a vector embedding.

This allows you to do Vector Search: searching based on meaning.

Want to learn more?

Check out this article: https://lnkd.in/dwu4f7dj

This is one of the simplest but very valuable AI features you can add to your applications.

---

author: Vojsava (Sava) Livadhi
first_line: A Mother's Plea: Seeking AlphaFold Experts for a Rare Cancer Mission
hook_150:
A Mother's Plea: Seeking AlphaFold Experts for a Rare Cancer Mission

This is the most important post I'll ever write. My son is turning 21 tomorrow,
full_text:
A Mother's Plea: Seeking AlphaFold Experts for a Rare Cancer Mission

This is the most important post I'll ever write. My son is turning 21 tomorrow, August 23rd. For the last 2.5 years, he has been bravely battling Alveolar Soft Part Sarcoma (ASPS), a rare and under-researched cancer.

ASPS is driven by a specific gene fusion protein (ASPSCR1-TFE3). This protein is the engine of his cancer, yet we lack a detailed understanding of its structure. This is where we see a path for hope, and where I desperately need your help.

We are searching for brilliant mindsâ€”individuals, researchers, or institutionsâ€”with expertise in using AlphaFold to create a 3D model of this specific fusion protein. Creating this structural "blueprint" is not just an academic exercise; it's a critical step that could allow us to identify this protein's vulnerabilities. The ultimate goal is to find existing, approved drugs that could be repurposed to "fit" and disable this engine, opening up new, out-of-the-box treatment strategies.

The power of the LinkedIn community is immense. A simple share could connect this plea to the one person or lab in the world that can help us move the needle in the fight against this rare disease.

My birthday wish for my son is hope, powered by action. Please, not only share this post but also ask your network to share it. You never know whose screen it might cross.

Thank you for your time and support.

#ASPS #AlveolarSoftPartSarcoma #RareCancer #CancerResearch #AlphaFold #DrugRepurposing #Sarcoma #Bioinformatics #ComputationalBiology #StructuralBiology #MedicalResearch #GoogleDeepMind #IsomorphicLab #GoogleAICoScientist
Please message me for any additional information vlivadhi@yahoo.com

hook_150: Big thanks to Jordan Cutler, author of the excellent, widely-read weekly newsletter High Growth Engineer. We teamed up on today's guest post in HGE ab
full_text:
Big thanks to Jordan Cutler, author of the excellent, widely-read weekly newsletter High Growth Engineer. We teamed up on today's guest post in HGE about storytelling (https://lnkd.in/e-38Pd66).

As you progress in your engineering career, the strong technical skills you've demonstrated won't be enough to get you promoted to the next level. They're necessary but not sufficient.

"What got you here won't get you there."

Storytelling skills are incredibly important everywhere, but especially in tech as you move to higher levels. The job will increasingly be about convincing others of your ideas on a larger and larger scale. Storytelling does just that.

You can check out the full storytelling post using the link above and subscribe to HGE here: https://lnkd.in/e3hrW-rc.

full_text:
I spent over $1,000 on an online writing course.

Here's why investing in writing is the best professional career move you can makeğŸ‘‡ğŸ½  

1ï¸âƒ£ Writing is the fastest way to build a professional brand

- My water & tech focused newsletter has gone from 0 -> 3,663 subscribers in just over 12 months

- Customers, partners, and connections all appreciate learning about you and your interests outside of what your company does

- Easy way to stay top of mind with people you don't often connect with.

2ï¸âƒ£ You can meet INCREDIBLE people from all over the world, many who become close friends and co-workers

- Writing online gives you 24/7 opportunities to find like minded people in places you may never visit in person. My life would be nowhere near as interesting without fellow writers like Cam, Robbie, Will, Stephen, Amanda, Karena, Florian, Louie, John, and Jim in it.

3ï¸âƒ£ Refining your thinking leads to better business outcomes

- Your ability to clearly and concisely convey messages in writing, especially in a remote world, directly impacts your ability to be successful at work.

- It's always nice to avoid an extra meeting when it can be taken care of in an e-mail or memo.

If you're interested in learning where to start, the team at Write of Passage is putting on a series of free webinars next month that talk about how to start writing online.

first_line: (R)evolution is here, we like it or not.
hook_150:
(R)evolution is here, we like it or not.


During the last Infoshare 2025 Conference Jordan Cutler showed this slide: The engineering team structure w
full_text:
(R)evolution is here, we like it or not.


During the last Infoshare 2025 Conference Jordan Cutler showed this slide: The engineering team structure we've known for years is changing, as we speak. Because AI and other tools / tech is more and more equipped in doing things for us, the skillset vs engineering role is shifting. 

ğŸ‘‰ Junior is becoming a Mid
ğŸ‘‰ Mid is becoming a Senior
ğŸ‘‰ Senior transforming into Staff Engineer (with a part of completely different skills)

I wanted to come back to it because we had a great conversation with Ari Block during our Leman Tech Leadership Podcast recording session. We've discussed how there are big predictions about engineering teams in overall. Interesting and necessary trend to follow, and build risk management around it. So we take care of our teams and businesses as well.

Do you see this transformation as well? Let's see what's already visible!

Learning from experienced people is the best way to level up as a developer.

first_line: Have ChatGPTs and other LLM based generative AI models already reached their zenith?
hook_150:
Have ChatGPTs and other LLM based generative AI models already reached their zenith?

AsÂ Louie BacajÂ says in the screenshot, once sites like StackOver
full_text:
Have ChatGPTs and other LLM based generative AI models already reached their zenith?

AsÂ Louie BacajÂ says in the screenshot, once sites like StackOverflow go, the quality of the content fed into LLMs goes down.

LLMs will also cannibalise themselves as they begin to feed off more and more LLM generated content.

Additionally, it's likely more sites will block LLMs from harvesting content as they're eating into their business models (as Twitter & Reddit already have).

So it's quite possible LLM output quality has already reached a zenith point (there are reports that OpenAI ChatGPT quality has already gone down, but due to cost saving efforts).

#aiÂ #generativeaiÂ #artificialintelligenceÂ #llmsÂ #largelanguagemodels

author: Aakash Gupta
first_line: Social media creates attention monsters. Instead of the most original thoughts, creators pursue the
hook_150: Social media creates attention monsters. Instead of the most original thoughts, creators pursue the strongest hooks. One startup wants to change that:
full_text:
Social media creates attention monsters. Instead of the most original thoughts, creators pursue the strongest hooks. One startup wants to change that:

How many layoff posts have you seen lately? Remote work copy-paste jobs?

When the incentive is to seek attention and get likes, behavior follows.

But compare social media to podcasts. The incentives are totally different. With a podcast feed, the creator is directly sending content to fans who have subscribed. So, instead, the incentive is for high QUALITY content.

Is it possible to create the same dynamic for writing? This inspired Chris, Hamish & Jairaj (pictured) to found Substack.

Their mission? â€œMake it simple to start a publication that makes money from subscriptions.â€ If they could create a new market of content, by making it economical for writers, they could create a new media.

So far, itâ€™s been working. The last time we got subscriber numbers from Substack, they had over 1M paying subscribers. That was up ~100% from the year prior. At an average cost of $7 per month, and 10% take rate, thatâ€™s a yearly revenue of $8.4M. Not bad for a company <6 years old.

Itâ€™s working out for its content creators, too. The top 10 writers make over $20M a year combined. Lenny Rachitsky shared he makes more on Substack than he did as a PM at Airbnb. Substack is set to be the next Twitch or YouTube, each of which have 10K+ creators living on them.

What product strategy and positioning has allowed Substack to get to this point?

1. Substack offers true independence for writers.

You own your email list. So, you can always walk away. This is totally different from Twitter, LinkedIn & Facebookâ€™s options.

2. Substack focuses on making the experience easy & simple.

Time to publish is super low. Compared to competitor ConvertKit, Substack offers less customization, analytics, and advertising monetization features. It just makes writing super simple.

3. Substack gets the fundamentals, like SEO & deliverability really right.

My 1 year old Substack crushes my Wordpress blog of 10 years on SEO. Others have measured the same for email deliverability vs other providers. Substack is #1 in the 2 most important areas.

Substack can pursue this focused positioning because it is built for one persona:

Â· Not for social media personalities. They might prefer Twitter or LinkedInâ€™s offerings
Â· Not for techies. They might prefer Wordpress or ConvertKit
Â· For writers who wants to focus on writing.

What can we learn from Substackâ€™s phenomenal product growth?

1. You can create wholly new markets, instead of competing in saturated oneâ€™s.
2. Simpler is better, especially if you have a focused persona.
3. Getting the basics really right, instead of just ok, is a great wedge.

author: Tanmay Munigala
first_line: I just finished Louie Bacaj's excellent "Timeless Career Advice For Software Engineers" course!
hook_150:
I just finished Louie Bacaj's excellent "Timeless Career Advice For Software Engineers" course!

Here are my top 10 takeaways from it:

1. Stick to st
full_text:
I just finished Louie Bacaj's excellent "Timeless Career Advice For Software Engineers" course!

Here are my top 10 takeaways from it:

1. Stick to startups/high-growth or big tech companies for a meaningful tech career

- Startups/high-growth companies to optimize for responsibility/scope
- Big tech companies to optimize for learning engineering best practices and compensation
- Work at companies where software directly ties to revenue (the product is the software itself)

2. Focus on ownership

- Stick to companies where software engineers are empowered to own and maintain their code (even after it's rolled out)
- Develop an ownership mindset - it's not your fault, but it's your responsibility

3. Deliver massive value

- What 20% of work will get you 80% of the results? Focus on that
- Make your code functional first
- Think about performance in B2C companies and maintainability in B2B companies

4. Develop an abundance mindset

- Find problems and opportunities to create more value in your product/system for your customers
- More problems you solve -> More resources for your company -> More rewards for you and your team

5. Build up your people skills

- Double down on relationships at work
- Empathise with your teammates and customers
- Learn to communicate effectively in conversations and meetings

6. Grow your influence through writing and speaking

- Write blog posts about your work - free credibility for you and your company
- Leverage opportunities to speak and present in meetings and presentations
- A public body of work >>> your resume
- Setup team and (eventually) company-wide initiatives. Ex: tech-talks, design reviews

7. Understand how promotions work

- Understand what the company values and deliver it. Different companies value different things
- Add value, make noise (in that order)
- Perform at the next level, and you'll be there soon

8. Leverage the power of 1 on 1 meetings

- Most important meetings of your career
- Take ownership of setting up 1 on 1's with key people - peers, product people, engineers and leaders (even from other teams) 

9. Nail your mid-year and annual reviews

- Take notes about your work and achievements weekly
- Write an excellent review for yourself

10. Master engineering concepts

- Data structures and algorithms
- One functional and one object-oriented language
- Design patterns and system design
- Concurrency and asynchronous programming
- Scalability, reliability and DevOps
- Domain-driven design

Lots more I couldn't cover here! 

Highly recommend checking it out for a holistic guide to a meaningful software engineering career - https://lnkd.in/gu4jWtXk

#careeradvice #softwareengineering #coding

full_text:
Today I'm launching my new book ğŸ‰

How do you grow beyond senior as a designer?

I've taken over 6 months to answer this question in the most actionable way in my new book.

Most senior designers do not want to become managers. So I focused on the IC-roles (whether it's called Staff, Lead, or Principal at your organization).

I researched how 50+ companies evaluate designers and employees, including Etsy, Medium, Dropbox, Square, Figma, Zendesk, and Intercom.

I also interviewed 19 product designers on their progression at Figma, Instacart, Dropbox, Etsy, Twitter, and smaller companies.

The book includes actionable techniques that helped other designers get promoted beyond senior: understanding business, finding project opportunities, setting standards, selling ideas, mentoring, increasing visibility, and more.

(If youâ€™re mid/junior-level, check out my previous book The Path to Senior Designer).

author: Curtis Einsmann
first_line: A common mistake of developers new to a "tech lead" role: trying to perform every code review. They'
hook_150: A common mistake of developers new to a "tech lead" role: trying to perform every code review. They're concerned that if they don't, something will br
full_text:
A common mistake of developers new to a "tech lead" role: trying to perform every code review. They're concerned that if they don't, something will break.

But reviewing every Pull Request isn't feasible, and doesn't scale.

So, what should you do instead? 6 tips:

1ï¸âƒ£ Enhance your delivery systems outside of code review.

Strengthen your release pipelines with tests, monitoring and rollback. This will help to prevent, detect and mitigate defects.

2ï¸âƒ£ Document code review processes.

Team members should be aware of the expected size, scope and structure for each PR. Add automated checks for testing and approval.

3ï¸âƒ£ Establish paradigms.

Introduce design patterns and structure to the codebase, that others can leverage and build on top of.

4ï¸âƒ£ Integrate automated tools.

Use linters and formatters to ensure consistent style. Set up automated static code analysis.

5ï¸âƒ£ Teach your team to review effectively.

Emphasize the importance of kindness, clarity, and thoroughness. Identify when blocking is or isn't appropriate.

6ï¸âƒ£ Be aware of what's being shipped to production.

Slack/GitHub integration works well. Know when to scan a pull request, and when to do a thorough dive.

ğŸ”‘ Remember: You can't write and review all the code for your team. If you could, hiring others would be pointless.

ğŸ’¡ Instead: put your team in position to ship better software, faster.

-----------
Like this post? It's an excerpt from my video course â€” Master the Code Review! Individual and team licenses available. ğŸ‘‰ https://buff.ly/3PEWlF6

#softwareengineering #codereview

full_text:
This is what engineers tend to focus on, depending on their level:
âœ… Junior Engineer: What tickets are mine?
âœ… Senior Engineer: How do we ship quality on time?
âœ… Staff Engineer: Why are we building this?

As a senior engineer, change your communication patterns accordingly (using empathy). With staff, focus more on the problems, vision, and strategy. With other seniors, focus on developer workflows and tools. To juniors, offer a predictable steady flow of meaningful work.

See chrislaffra.com/c4e for more information.

full_text:
â€œAsk and you shall receive.â€
But in leadership, itâ€™s often the opposite.

Give and only then you shall receive. ğŸ‘‡

Give energy + engagement to get more energy + engagement.
Give more responsibility, in order to get more responsibility.

Give open communication, to get open communication.
Give trust, in order to be trusted.

Instead leaders inadvertently often do the opposite.Â 
Eg expecting people to trust them, but donâ€™t trust their own people.

Leadership is an amplification mechanism.Â 
Whatever you do gets amplified and comes back to you 10X.Â 
There is nowhere to hide. 

You can do the opposite but itâ€™s not sustainable in the long run.
This is not a morality position.
Rather, itâ€™s a performance position. 

Teams with the above characteristics simply outperform others in the long run.

Which one would you rather have?

#leadership #management

author: Charchris Sloan
first_line: Now is the time to upskill. Stop thinking about how AI will eliminate your role and start thinking a
hook_150: Now is the time to upskill. Stop thinking about how AI will eliminate your role and start thinking about how it will elevate it. Jordan Cutlerâ€™s advic
full_text:
Now is the time to upskill. Stop thinking about how AI will eliminate your role and start thinking about how it will elevate it. Jordan Cutlerâ€™s advice? Diversify your skillset:

â€œDevelop your people and AI skills, use AI to solve problems and ensure you have the people skills to work with *anyone*â€.

He advises entry-level engineers to follow the 3 Eâ€™s framework:

- Education: Evolve your understanding of the foundations, for example, embeddings and AI's probabilistic nature and randomness. There are AI courses on Udemy that can help.

- Exposure: Curate your â€œinformation dietâ€ and read content from credible experts (e.g., Ruben Hassid), whether in newsletters or following them on LinkedIn.

- Experience: Start building products. AI can guide you to an output, and youâ€™ll quickly understand whether your code has worked.

For more tenured engineers, he recommends using AI to improve communication and design better systems:
- Use tools like v0 to get to a higher fidelity prototype with minimal effort
- Use tools like WriteEdge and @chatPRD to discuss/debate ideas

In summary: use AI to reduce the â€œtime to valueâ€ for a product

We discuss this and more in this weekâ€™s edition of Hiring Humans (We also share some great resources to feed your information diet too ğŸ‘€)

author: Danny Martinez
first_line: Software engineering is not dead. Far from it. Jordan Cutler, senior software engineer at Pinterest
hook_150: Software engineering is not dead. Far from it. Jordan Cutler, senior software engineer at Pinterest and author of the High Growth Engineer newsletter
full_text:
Software engineering is not dead. Far from it. Jordan Cutler, senior software engineer at Pinterest and author of the High Growth Engineer newsletter (>80k subscribers), says:

Our expectations for each level of software engineer have changed.

If you were previously a junior engineer who needed handholding to start writing code, you could use AI to write code like a mid-level engineer.

Mid-level engineers can use AI to produce the output of a senior engineer. A senior engineer + AI = a Staff engineer, and so on and so forth.

â­ï¸ In next weekâ€™s edition of Hiring Humans, Charchris Sloan, Jordan, and I discuss:

- The advice Jordan gives to entry-level software engineers
- The importance of the â€œinformation dietâ€ for keeping up with AI developments
- How to use AI to improve communication and design better systems
- The engineering skills that companies will interview for in the future

ğŸ—“ï¸ Post dropping on 06/02

first_line: As engineers, our greatest tool isnâ€™t our code.

full_text:
As engineers, our greatest tool isnâ€™t our code.

Itâ€™s our writing.

Writing helps us share ideas, align teams, and explain decisions. 

Writing well makes everything clearer and more impactful.

Hereâ€™s how I write better at work:

1/ Know your audience: Who will read this? What do they already know? Tailor your writing to their needs.

2/ Clarify your core message: What am I trying to convey? Use short sentences. Avoid jargon when possible.

3/ Continuously edit your work: Your first draft is never perfect. I always read and tweak my writing multiple times.

4/ Seek feedback from senior folks: Reach out to senior engineers to review and give feedback. Their perspectives are valuable.

P.S. Want to write like a senior engineer? Jordan Cutler and I are launching WriteEdge â€“ a platform to help you write tech specs & project updates like a senior engineer. Get simulated feedback from tech leads, product managers, and CTOs. Check it out:

You start by dividing the possible root causes into high-level groups. Then, you break these groups down further, ensuring every possibility is captured and none of the buckets overlap.

Donâ€™t rely on luck to find the root cause. The MECE framework gives you a structure that ensures you will find it, and makes it easy to:

full_text:
In the Tech layoffs era, the best thing a Software Engineer or an Engineering Manager can do is to stay ahead of the curve by keeping their skills up to date and as sharp as possible. How to do that? Read tech newsletters! Here are 12 of the best personally vetted newsletters everybody should read.

1/ The Pragmatic Engineer by Gergely Orosz - https://lnkd.in/gQ6NfATy
My absolute favorite newsletter, covering a variety of topics from in-depth analysis of how various companies do things to general solid advice on career growth and engineering management.

2/ Level Up Software Engineering by Caleb Mellas - https://lnkd.in/gmAhnDHW
Empathetic career development tips for software engineers looking to develop both technical and interpersonal skills.

3/ Software Design: Tidy First? by Kent Beck - https://lnkd.in/gwvWkpE8
Excellent mix of technical and non-technical advice from the author of Extreme Programming and TDD. 

4/ Engineer's Codex - https://lnkd.in/gGcf3Nax
Case studies and practical lessons from Big Tech companies.

5/ ByteByteGo Newsletter by Alex Xu - https://lnkd.in/geMg5AnP
Weekly in-depth systems design newsletter, written by the author of â€œSystems Designâ€ vol 1 and vol 2.

6/ High Growth Engineer by Jordan Cutler - https://lnkd.in/giieDcyr
Practical actionable advice for ambitious engineers looking to grow in their careers.

7/ Engineering Leadership by Gregor Ojstersek - https://lnkd.in/gPHYeBN6
Engineering/Engineering Leadership topics to help you become a great engineering leader.

8/ SeattleDataGuyâ€™s Newsletter by Benjamin Rogojan - https://lnkd.in/gnFB7J8a
The best data engineering newsletter, insightful even if you donâ€™t work in data.

9/ Hybrid Hacker by Nicola Ballotta - https://lnkd.in/g9fMdk2k
In-depth lessons on engineering management with excellent illustrations.

10/ Wes Kaoâ€™s Newsletter - https://lnkd.in/geJNC3PN
Excellent advice on navigating work dynamics and career growth from the co-founder of Maven.

11/ System Design Newsletter by Neo Kim - https://lnkd.in/gZyW5kQy
Easy-to-understand explanations of complex architectures.

12/ And lastly, me ğŸ˜Š with â€œThe Caring Techie Newsletterâ€ - https://lnkd.in/gYBS3EMe
My newsletter focuses on soft skills, communication, and building caring leaders and it's based on my experience at Big Tech (Google, Uber) and early-stage startups.

Iâ€™m sure I missed a ton of excellent ones, so please add them in the comments!!

full_text:
Most teams get microservices communication wrong.

They obsess over APIs and forget the real problem: coupling and reliability.

In my latest video, I break down how microservices should actually talk to each other. Youâ€™ll see where synchronous (HTTP, gRPC) calls make sense, and where you should switch to asynchronous messaging with queues and topics.

I also cover real .NET examples with Azure Service Bus, Redis, and distributed tracing, so you can see how to design communication thatâ€™s fast, reliable, and easy to reason about.

Check it out here: https://lnkd.in/eGB3WUqW

If youâ€™re building or refactoring a microservices system, this will save you a lot of pain later.

author: Alex Xu
first_line: Top Software Architectural Styles.
hook_150:
Top Software Architectural Styles. 

In software development, architecture plays a crucial role in shaping the structure and behavior of software syst
full_text:
Top Software Architectural Styles. 

In software development, architecture plays a crucial role in shaping the structure and behavior of software systems. It provides a blueprint for system design, detailing how components interact with each other to deliver specific functionality. They also offer solutions to common problems, saving time and effort and leading to more robust and maintainable systems.

However, with the vast array of architectural styles and patterns available, it can take time to discern which approach best suits a particular project or system. Aims to shed light on these concepts, helping you make informed decisions in your architectural endeavors.

To help you navigate the vast landscape of architectural styles and patterns, there is a cheat sheet that encapsulates all. This cheat sheet is a handy reference guide that you can use to quickly recall the main characteristics of each architectural style and pattern.

--
Subscribe to our weekly newsletter to get a Free System Design PDF (368 pages): https://lnkd.in/grvckqjv

#systemdesign #coding #interviewtipsÂ 
.

author: Nicola Ballotta
first_line: As you might have noticed, I had to take a forced pause from LinkedIn last week.
hook_150:
As you might have noticed, I had to take a forced pause from LinkedIn last week.


I was at Cloudfest for work, and although I could have scheduled al
full_text:
As you might have noticed, I had to take a forced pause from LinkedIn last week.


I was at Cloudfest for work, and although I could have scheduled all my LinkedIn posts over the previous weekend, I preferred to take a week off to spend time with family, whom I wouldn't see for a week.

As someone who has always promoted consistency and who has regularly posted five times a week for months, you start to:

ğŸ”„ Feel that you're breaking your consistency habit.

ğŸ¢ Worry that others will progress faster since you're taking a pause.

ğŸš§ Fear that what you've built will be disrupted.

This is what they call FOMO - the Fear of Missing Out.

But building consistency doesn't mean overdoing it to the point of burnout.

As I've often said, it takes time to build consistency and habits, but fortunately, it takes much more than a week of "rest" to disrupt them.

Taking a break is sometimes just a part of your journey towards consistency and it offers multiple benefits:

ğŸ’­ It gives you time to reflect on your journey towards consistency.

ğŸ§  It allows your brain to refresh and generate new ideas.

ğŸ”¥ It helps prevent burnout, which could set you back much more than a week.

So, even if you're on your journey to consistency, don't let FOMO guide you. Have a clear path to your goals and make pauses part of it.

â™»ï¸ PLEASE REPOST IF YOU FOUND IT USEFUL, IT MEANS A LOT TO ME.

---
ğŸ”” Enjoy my posts? Hit the bell and follow me â†’ Nicola Ballotta 
ğŸ¤“ Consider subscribing to The Hybrid Hacker newsletter (link in the first comment)

#consistency #productivity #fomo #burnout #cloudfest

Donâ€™t screw people. Donâ€™t burn bridges.

Especially if you are in the tech industry, itâ€™s a much smaller world than we may think.

Credibility compounds over time, but it can be lost instantly.

There is no better way to grow than growing together with people who are on a similar path than you.

The path is much more:

- faster and
- overall better.

Compete with yourself only and get better every day.

first_line: Your database isn't slow.
hook_150:
Your database isn't slow.

Your indexing strategy is.

Most developers treat SQL indexes like a "magic button". You add one to a column, the query get
full_text:
Your database isn't slow.

Your indexing strategy is.

Most developers treat SQL indexes like a "magic button". You add one to a column, the query gets faster, and you move on.

But what happens when your table hits 10 million rows and that "magic" disappears?

I just dropped a deep dive into how SQL indexing actually works under the hood.

I took a standard PostgreSQL query from 21ms down to 0.02ms (a 1,000x performance gain) by understanding three core concepts.

Learn more: https://lnkd.in/diNSHk3Z

author: Alex Xu
first_line: Top 20 System Design Concepts You Should Know
hook_150:
Top 20 System Design Concepts You Should Know

1. Load Balancing: Distributes traffic across multiple servers for reliability and availability.
2. Cac
full_text:
Top 20 System Design Concepts You Should Know

1. Load Balancing: Distributes traffic across multiple servers for reliability and availability.
2. Caching: Stores frequently accessed data in memory for faster access.
3. Database Sharding: Splits databases to handle large-scale data growth.
4. Replication: Copies data across replicas for availability and fault tolerance.
5. CAP Theorem: Trade-off between consistency, availability, and partition tolerance.
6. Consistent Hashing: Distributes load evenly in dynamic server environments.
7. Message Queues: Decouples services using asynchronous event-driven architecture.
8. Rate Limiting: Controls request frequency to prevent system overload.
9. API Gateway: Centralized entry point for routing API requests.
10. Microservices: Breaks systems into independent, loosely coupled services.
11. Service Discovery: Locates services dynamically in distributed systems.
12. CDN: Delivers content from edge servers for speed.
13. Database Indexing: Speeds up queries by indexing important fields.
14. Data Partitioning: Divides data across nodes for scalability and performance.
15. Eventual Consistency: Guarantees consistency over time in distributed databases
16. WebSockets: Enables bi-directional communication for live updates.
17. Scalability: Increases capacity by upgrading or adding machines.
18. Fault Tolerance: Ensures system availability during hardware/software failures.
19. Monitoring: Tracks metrics and logs to understand system health.
20. Authentication & Authorization: Controls user access and verifies identity securely.

Over to you: Which other System Design concept will you add to the list?

--

first_line: I'm a natural-born procrastinator and  I'm not ashamed to admit it. However, I have one secret to ov
hook_150:
I'm a natural-born procrastinator and  I'm not ashamed to admit it. However, I have one secret to overcoming it.


 ğŸš€ I call it MAG, which stands for
full_text:
I'm a natural-born procrastinator and  I'm not ashamed to admit it. However, I have one secret to overcoming it.


 ğŸš€ I call it MAG, which stands for Minimum Achievable Goal.


1ï¸âƒ£ I wake up every morning, and I lie in bed for 10 minutes listing all my goals for the day. They are usually a lot and very ambitious.

I wish I could achieve all of them, but I know I can't.

2ï¸âƒ£ While walking back from taking my daughter to kindergarten, I begin reviewing all these goals and I cut down what isn't a priority, until I'm left with three main goals for the day.

But that's not enough.

3ï¸âƒ£ As soon as I'm back home, I start my journaling session; this is where I set my main goal for the day.

Just one.

This unique goal is what I absolutely have to achieve during the day.

Does this mean I'll work on just one task per day? 

Obviously not.

But focusing on just one main task when you tend to procrastinate has multiple benefits:

ğŸ˜” Procrastinating feels bad. Having just one goal to achieve increases chances to feel successful during the day.

ğŸ”¥ As soon as you find yourself procrastinating, you immediately know where to switch your focus instead of thinking about all your goals.

ğŸ”‹ Achieving just one goal is easier, and when you do, you'll get energized by this, ending up wanting to achieve more goals.

And you? How do you fight procrastination?

full_text:
As humans, thereâ€™s undoubtedly one thing we continuously do, sometimes without even realizing it. 


âš–ï¸ Taking decisions. 

Think about it. Every action we take involves some level of decision-making, and making decisions for ourselves can sometimes be challenging.

Now, imagine the complexities of decision-making within an engineering team, where multiple individuals, possibly from diverse cultures and backgrounds, are involved.

I wish I could offer you a secret recipe for making decisions in this context, but, unfortunately, it doesnâ€™t exist (believe me, Iâ€™ve searched for it for 10 years).

However, having robust decision-making processes within your engineering team is crucial. 

Here are the benefits:

ğŸ”¥ Focuses effort
ğŸ”„ Ensures consistency
â³ Saves time
ğŸ§­ Provides direction
ğŸ›¡ï¸ Builds resilience

So, how do you make decisions? 

There are many different approaches, including:

ğŸª– Autocratic
ğŸ§  Experiential
ğŸš€ Empowered Autonomy
ğŸ“Š Data-Driven
ğŸ—³ï¸ Majority Rule
âœ… Consensus

Choosing your approach depends on various factors, such as:

- Your role and leadership style
- Your risk aversion
- Your relationship with stakeholders
- Your team's culture
- Your company's environment
- The specific nature of the decisions to be made

And particularly, the area in which you must make those decisions.

Yes, itâ€™s a lot to digest, but youâ€™re lucky.

hook_150:
What is Claims Transformation in ASPNET Core?

You can use it to extend your authorization logic by adding dynamic claims at runtime.

If your Identit
full_text:
What is Claims Transformation in ASPNET Core?

You can use it to extend your authorization logic by adding dynamic claims at runtime.

If your Identity Provider's access token doesn't perfectly align with your application's internal authorization needs, you can use claims transformation.

Claims transformation allows you to modify the claims before the application uses them for authorization.

You can use this to fill in the missing claims from your database or another source.

Here's why this is helpful: https://lnkd.in/eMsd69UY

Did you run a situation like this in your projects?

author: Alex Xu
first_line: Virtualization vs. Containerization
hook_150:
Virtualization vs. Containerization

Before containers simplified deployment, virtualization changed how we used hardware. Both isolate workloads, but
full_text:
Virtualization vs. Containerization

Before containers simplified deployment, virtualization changed how we used hardware. Both isolate workloads, but they do it differently.

- Virtualization (Hardware-level isolation): Each virtual machine runs a complete operating system, Windows, Fedora, or Ubuntu, with its own kernel, drivers, and libraries. The hypervisor (VMware ESXi, Hyper-V, KVM) sits directly on hardware and emulates physical machines for each guest OS. 

This makes VMs heavy but isolated. Need Windows and Linux on the same box? VMs handle it easily. Startup time for a typical VM is in minutes because you're booting an entire operating system from scratch.

- Containerization (OS-level isolation): Containers share the host operating system's kernel. No separate OS per container. Just isolated processes with their own filesystem and dependencies.

The container engine (Docker, containerd, CRI-O, Podman) manages lifecycle, networking, and isolation, but it all runs on top of a single shared kernel. Lightweight and fast. Containers start in milliseconds because you're not booting an OS, just launching a process.

But here's the catch: all containers on a host must be compatible with that host's kernel. Can't run Windows containers on a Linux host (without nested virtualization tricks).

Over to you: What's your go-to setup: containers in VMs, bare metal containers, or something else?

--

first_line: Implementing resilience in .NET? You better...
hook_150:
Implementing resilience in .NET? You better...

Polly is probably your first choice.

And Polly is much faster in V8+.

But why should you care about
full_text:
Implementing resilience in .NET? You better...

Polly is probably your first choice.

And Polly is much faster in V8+.

But why should you care about making your application resilient?

Let's say your services communicate by sending HTTP requests.

HTTP requests can fail because of network or server issues.

These failures can disrupt service availability, especially as dependencies increase. This increases the risk of cascading failures.

Luckily, there's a simple way to solve this in your .NET applications.

Here's how you can make your apps resilient: https://lnkd.in/e39__DXH

Do you use Polly in your applications?

There's also an official resilience library in .NET.

But it's a wrapper around Polly that adds OpenTelemetry on top.

author: Gregor Ojstersek
first_line: I can tell a lot about engineer's seniority by the way they approach solving problems.
hook_150:
I can tell a lot about engineer's seniority by the way they approach solving problems.

Here are 5 indicators that tell me if the engineer has a Senio
full_text:
I can tell a lot about engineer's seniority by the way they approach solving problems.

Here are 5 indicators that tell me if the engineer has a Senior mindset:

1. They ask all the right questions before they start solving the problem.

2. They REALLY take care of the problem, not just try to quickly patch it and leave it for others to deal with.

3. They focus on simplifying the solution as much as possible.

4. They know when the solution is good enough or when to optimize further.

5. They are self-aware and self-confident enough to admit when they don't know something.

What indicators would you add?

In just ab
full_text:
Yesterday, I achieved a significant milestone much sooner than I ever expected.

ğŸš€ 20,000 subscribers to my newsletter, The Hybrid Hacker.

In just about 13 months. Back in November, I was at 9k, which means I nearly doubled my subscriber count in the last three months.

These numbers are all relative. I know of people who grew much faster, and others slower. As I often say, statistics only give you a perception of growth.

What truly confirms my growth is:

ğŸ“š The amount I've learned from writing
â†³ Writing not only enhanced my consistency but also significantly broadened my knowledge, including a big improvement in my English.

ğŸ‘¥ The number of people I've connected with during this period.
â†³ Despite being an introvert and often hesitant about networking, I met 100+ great people in the last year, some of whom I've developed genuine relationships with.

ğŸ™ People who reached out to thank me for my writing.
â†³ Here on LinkedIn alone, I have an endless backlog of DMs awaiting my response (I promise to reply to all, as always!). These messages range from thanks and support requests to simple greetings.

ğŸ’– And, of course, those who chose to support me with a paid subscription.
â†³ Currently, I have 111 paid subscribers. While this isn't a business for me (I have my full-time job), the income helps me purchase tools, newsletter subscriptions, courses, etc., to enhance my content quality. It's also incredibly rewarding to see people willing to pay for what I create.

Considering these four "KPIs", I can confidently say my growth was exponential.

So, how did I achieve these numbers?

Two factors were key:

- Consistency

first_line: Why Is Nginx So Popular?
hook_150:
Why Is Nginx So Popular?

Apache dominated web servers for 20 years, then Nginx showed up and changed everything. Now Nginx powers some of the largest
full_text:
Why Is Nginx So Popular?

Apache dominated web servers for 20 years, then Nginx showed up and changed everything. Now Nginx powers some of the largest sites on the internet, including Netflix, Airbnb, Dropbox, and WordPress. com. Not because it's newer or trendier, but because it solves problems that Apache couldn't handle efficiently. 

Hereâ€™s what makes Nginx so popular:

- High-Performance Web Server
- Reverse Proxy & Load Balancer
- Caching Layer
- SSL Termination (Offloading)

Over to you: Whatâ€™s your primary use for Nginx today, web server, reverse proxy, or load balancer?

author: Alex Xu
first_line: The HTTP Mindmap
hook_150:
The HTTP Mindmap

HTTP has evolved from HTTP/1.1 to HTTP/2, and now HTTP/3, which uses the QUIC protocol over UDP for improved performance. Today, itâ€™
full_text:
The HTTP Mindmap

HTTP has evolved from HTTP/1.1 to HTTP/2, and now HTTP/3, which uses the QUIC protocol over UDP for improved performance. Today, itâ€™s the backbone of almost everything on the internet, from browsers and APIs to streaming, cloud, and AI systems.

At the foundation, we have underlying protocols. TCP/IP for IPv4 and IPv6 traffic. Unix domain sockets for local communication. HTTP/3 running over UDP instead of TCP. These handle the actual data transport before HTTP even comes into play.

Security wraps around everything. HTTPS isn't optional anymore. WebSockets power real-time connections. Web servers manage workloads. CDNs distribute content globally. DNS resolves everything to IPs. Proxies (forward, reverse, and API gateways) route, filter, and secure traffic in between.

Web services exchange data in different formats, REST with JSON, SOAP for enterprise systems, RPC for direct calls, and GraphQL for flexible queries. Crawlers and bots index the web, guided by robots.txt files that set the boundaries.

The network world connects everything. LANs, WANs, and protocols like FTP for file transfers, IMAP/POP3 for email, and BitTorrent for peer-to-peer communication. For observability, packet capture tools like Wireshark, tcpdump, and OpenTelemetry let developers peek under the hood to understand performance, latency, and behavior across the stack.

Over to you: HTTP has been evolving for 30+ years, what do you think the next big shift will be?

--

author: Milan JovanoviÄ‡
first_line: Data Annotations are great for simple things.
hook_150:
Data Annotations are great for simple things.

[Required]? Fine.
[MaxLength(50)]? Sure.

But what happens when you need to validate something against
full_text:
Data Annotations are great for simple things.

[Required]? Fine.
[MaxLength(50)]? Sure.

But what happens when you need to validate something against a database?
Or validate based on a configuration setting in appsettings.json?

Data Annotations hit a wall. You can't easily inject dependencies into an Attribute.

This is where FluentValidation shines.

Because your validators are just standard classes registered in the DI container, you can inject anything you need.

Want to check if a CouponCode is valid by calling the IPricingService? Just inject it into the OrderValidator constructor.

It turns validation from a static check into a dynamic, intelligent logic layer.

I explain how to wire this up seamlessly in ASPNET Core here: https://lnkd.in/d9nVR8fu

It is a game changer for complex business rules.

---

first_line: Did you check out the resilience improvements in .NET 9?
hook_150:
Did you check out the resilience improvements in .NET 9?

We have two official NuGet packages:

- Microsoft.Extensions.Resilience
- Microsoft.Extensio
full_text:
Did you check out the resilience improvements in .NET 9?

We have two official NuGet packages:

- Microsoft.Extensions.Resilience
- Microsoft.Extensions.Http.Resilience

They're built on top of Polly, so the API should be familiar. You can use them to define resilience policies in C#.

They extend Polly with some useful features. For example, a standard pipeline you can add to HttpClients. There's also an OpenTelemetry integration.

A few strategies that are available out of the box:

- Retries
- Timeouts
- Fallbacks
- Circuit breakers

Want to learn more about resilience in .NET?

Start here: https://lnkd.in/dzmqjFuC

If this saves you from even one network failure, it'll be worth it.

---

author: Milan JovanoviÄ‡
first_line: Cursor pagination is blazing fast.
hook_150:
Cursor pagination is blazing fast.

But it's not a good solution for every situation. Here's why. ğŸ‘‡

Cursor pagination uses a reference point (cursor)
full_text:
Cursor pagination is blazing fast.

But it's not a good solution for every situation. Here's why. ğŸ‘‡

Cursor pagination uses a reference point (cursor) to fetch the next page of results.

This reference point must be a unique identifier or a combination of fields that define the sort order.

My tests showed cursor pagination was 17x faster compared to offset pagination.

So why don't we always use it?

Cursor pagination works particularly well for real-time feeds and infinite scroll interfaces.

If most users start at the first page and rarely visit other pages, offset pagination might be sufficient. This will be the case for many applications.

Want to learn more about cursor pagination?

Here's an implementation guide + performance analysis: https://lnkd.in/eS2h4CgC

Did you ever implement cursor pagination?

author: Milan JovanoviÄ‡
first_line: I spent 2 days speeding up an API endpoint...
hook_150:
I spent 2 days speeding up an API endpoint...

And I made it 15x faster.

The endpoint did heavy calculations and pulled data from several services, s
full_text:
I spent 2 days speeding up an API endpoint...

And I made it 15x faster.

The endpoint did heavy calculations and pulled data from several services, so it didnâ€™t scale.

My process was simple:

- Find the slowest code
- Fix the queries
- Cut external calls
- Add caching last

Measure everything. The slow parts were obvious:

- DB calls inside a loop
- Repeated external calls
- Duplicate calculations

Database round trips cost time, so avoid loops and batch what you can.

Independent service calls? Run them concurrently.

Still slow? Add caching with clear expiration rules (IMemoryCache / IDistributedCache).

For distributed systems, OpenTelemetry makes the bottlenecks visible.

ğŸ‘‰ Hereâ€™s how: https://lnkd.in/dsxuMvmz

What would you do differently?

author: Milan JovanoviÄ‡
first_line: 5 EF Core features you need to know ğŸ¦„
hook_150:
5 EF Core features you need to know ğŸ¦„

EF Core is fast, but only if you use the right tools.

Here are 5 features that will speed up your data access:
full_text:
5 EF Core features you need to know ğŸ¦„

EF Core is fast, but only if you use the right tools.

Here are 5 features that will speed up your data access:

1. Query Splitting: Stops "Cartesian Explosion" by breaking huge JOINs into separate SQL queries.

2. Bulk Updates: ExecuteUpdate() modifies rows directly in the DB. Zero memory allocation.

3. Bulk Deletes: ExecuteDelete() wipes data instantly without fetching it first.

4. Raw SQL: Sometimes LINQ generates bad SQL. Raw SQL lets you take the wheel for complex queries.

5. IgnoreQueryFilters: Perfect for Admin dashboards where you need to see "Soft Deleted" data or tenant-specific records.

Bonus: I covered 5 more advanced features in this article: https://lnkd.in/dxbAfjUR

Which one of these saved your production app?

author: Milan JovanoviÄ‡
first_line: How do you handle a transaction that spans 3 different microservices?
hook_150:
How do you handle a transaction that spans 3 different microservices?

You can't use a standard Database Transaction (ACID) because the data lives in
full_text:
How do you handle a transaction that spans 3 different microservices?

You can't use a standard Database Transaction (ACID) because the data lives in different places.

You need a Saga.

And a Saga is essentially just a State Machine with memory.

It tracks the progress of a workflow:

1. Current State: "OrderPlaced"
2. Event: "PaymentReceived"
3. Transition: Move to "OrderPaid" state and send a command to the Shipping Service.

If something fails (e.g., "ShippingFailed"), the State Machine triggers a specific "Compensating Action" to undo the previous steps (e.g., Issue Refund).

It turns chaos into a deterministic workflow.

You can see a full code example of an Order Saga here: https://lnkd.in/d6jY3KaP

Sagas are complex at first, but they are a lifesaver for data consistency.

---

first_line: Most developers get this system design question completely wrong.
hook_150:
Most developers get this system design question completely wrong.

And years ago, I was one of them.

The scenario was simple:
A user clicks â€œGenerate
full_text:
Most developers get this system design question completely wrong.

And years ago, I was one of them.

The scenario was simple:
A user clicks â€œGenerate Report.â€
The API takes 5 minutes to finish.
What do you change?

Back then, I tried to â€œoptimizeâ€ the slow part... faster queries, better hardware, parallelization.
None of that solved the real problem.

The issue wasnâ€™t performance.
It was the architecture.

Hereâ€™s what I learned:

â€¢ Donâ€™t run long tasks in an HTTP request
â€¢ Use a queue and a background worker
â€¢ Return 202 Accepted instead of blocking
â€¢ Store the final file in object storage
â€¢ Notify the user when the work is done (SignalR / email / polling)

This simple question changed how I think about system design.
It taught me to design workflows, not endpoints.

I recorded a full breakdown here: https://lnkd.in/etjZHbqA
